Is it not that my virtue is insufficient and my teachings lacking in enlightenment?
I an filled with the deepest shame!
Thus it is that if the leadership and guidance of the ruler are not sincere the people in their ignorance will fall into crime.
The Book of Odes says: Just and gentle is the true prince,
Father and mother to his people.77
Now, when men have some fault,
punishments are imposed upon them before they have even been taught what is right,
so that although they may wish to mend their actions and do good, there is no way open for them.
I am deeply grieved at this.
Punishments which extend to the cutting off of limbs
or the piercing of flesh,
leaving the victim maimed for life,
are unspeakably cruel and unjust.
How can a ruler who countenances such things be called a "father and a mother to his people"?
Let the mutilating punishments be abolished!78
The emperor announced:
Agriculture
is the basis of the empire.
Among the endeavors of man, none is more important.
Yet at present those who labor at agricultural pursuits still have to pay both the land tax and the produce tax.
In this respect there is no difference made between the fundamental pursuits of agriculture and the secondary pursuits of trade.
This is surely not the proper way to encourage agriculture.
middle Western Han
The emperor went himself to comfort and exhort the troops,
announcing to them their orders
and preseting gifts to the officers and men.
It was the emperor's desire to lead them in person against the Xiong-nu and,
although his officials remonstrated with him,
he refused to heed them.
It was not until his mother, Empress Dowager Bo, pleaded with him
that he abandoned the idea.
Instead he appointed Zhang Xiang-ru, the marquis of Dong-yang, as general in chief;
Dong-chi, the marquis of Cheng, as prefect of the capital;
and Luan-bu as a general
and sent them to attack the Xiong-nu.
The Xiong-nu fled from the land.
In the spring
the emperor announced:
For fourteen year now
I have been allowed to present the sacrificial victims, the jade tablets, and offerings of silk in the service of the Lord on High and the ancestral temples.
The days are long in which,
with neither wisdom nor understanding, I have watched over the empire,
and I am filled with shame.
Let the altars and altar grounds be broadened and the jade tablets and silks for the various sacrifices be increased.
Though the kings of ancient times spread their goodness abroad, they did not seek for any reward.
Though they sacrificed to the mountains and rivers, they did not pray for their own good fortune.
They honored the wise above all and considered their own kin second;
they put the people first and themselves last.
Theirs was the highest order of wisdom.
Now I have heard that, when the sacrificial officials pray for blessings,
they ask that all the good fortune may come to me in person,
and say nothing of the common people.
I am deeply shamed by this.
Am I, who am without virtue,
alone to enjoy good fortune and receive blessings,
and are my people to have no part in them?
This is only to double my lack of virtue!
Let the sacrificial officials conduct their duties with all due reverence,
but let them not pray for such blessings!
Zhang Cang, the marquis of Bei-ping, who at this time was acting as chancellor,
was very learned in matters of the pitch pipes and the calendar.
It happened that a man of Lu named Gong-sun Chen submitted a letter to the authorities expounding the manner in which the five elements succeed each other in a continuous cycle,
and stating that the present age was under the dominance of the element earth.
As proof of this, he asserted, a yellow dragon would appear, yellow being the color of the element earth.

He therefore believed it appropriate for the dynasty to change the month on which the year began, to alter the color of the vestments, and to change other regulations of the government to accord with this fact.
The emperor referred the matter to his ministers and deliberated on it with the chancellor Zhang Cang.
But Zhang Cang, insisting that the element water was clearly in the ascendancy,
asserted that the dynasty should honor black, the color of the element water, and continue to begin the year with the tenth month.
He regarded Gong-sun Chen's assertions as completely false
and requested that they be disregarded.
In the fifteenth year
a yellow dragon appeared at Cheng-ji,
and the emperor reopened the matter, summoning Gong-sun Chen to court
and making him an erudit,
with instructions to explain in full his theory of the ascendance of teh element earth.
The emperor then issued an edict saying:
A supernatural being in the form of a strange creature has appeared at Cheng-ji,
but no harm will come to the people,
and the year will be a plentiful one.
I wish in person to perform the suburban sacrifice to the Lord on High and to the other spirits.
Let the officials in charge of rites deliberate on the matter.
Let them not hesitate in their recommendations for fear of putting me to too much trouble.
The officials in charge of rites all replied,
"It was customary for the Son of Heaven in ancient times to proceed to the suburbs in the summer to sacrifice in person to the Lord on High.
Hence this was called the 'suburban sacrifice.'"
In accordance with their instruction the emperor for the first time paid a visit to Yong
and performed the suburban sacrifice to the Emperors of the Five Directions.
The ceremony was performed in the fourth month, the first month of summer.
A man of Zhao named Xin-yuan Ping, appearing before the emperor to report an unusual cloud formation he had seen,
advised the emperor to set up temples to the Five Emperors north of the Wei River.
He requested that a search be made for the cauldrons of Zhou
and predicted that a jade of extraordinary beauty would appear.79
In the sixteenth year
the emperor in person performed the suburban sacrifice at the temples of the Five Emperors.
Because, like the previous ceremony, this one was also performed in the summer, the highest honor was paid to red, the color of the summer season.
In the seventeenth year
a jade cup was found
bearing the inscription "Long Life to the Lord of Men."
Because of this the emperor began to number the years of his reign over again, calling this year the "first year."
He ordered that there be great feasting and drinking throughout the empire.
In the same year
it was discovered that the jade cup and the other signs and wonders reported by Xin-yuan Ping were all frauds,
and he was executed along with his three sets of relatives.
In the second year of the latter part of his reign
the emperor announced:
I am without understanding
and have been unable to spread virtue abroad,
and so I have not brought order and quiet to the lands beyond our borders.
Thus the people who dwell in the wastelands that surround China are not at peace in their way of life,
while those within our realm labor and find no rest.
Both of these faults have come about
because my virtue is insufficient and has failed to penetrate to distant regions.
For several years past
the Xiong-nu have repeatedly violated our borders
and killed many of our officials and people,
while the ministers and troops stationed on the border have been unable to convince them of my good will.
Thus the evidence of my lack of virtue has been doubled.
Yet, if we were to continue to face them as enemies and join our troops in battle,
how would peace ever be brought to our country and theirs?
I have risen early and retired late,
laboring for the sake of the empire
and taking thought for the people:
for them I have been filled with concern and unrest,
and their troubles have not left my mind for a single day.
Therefore I have dispatched envoys in such profusion that their caps and cart covers are within sight of each other on the road,
and their wheel tracks are joined,
in order to explain my intentions to the Chan-yu, the ruler of the Xiong-nu.
At last the Chan-yu has returned to the wise ways of earlier times and,
to insure the safety of the sacred altars of the soil and grain
and to bring benefit to the common people,
has joined with me anew. Together we have cast aside our petty faults
and together we will walk the higher road of virtue.
We have united ourselves in bonds of brotherhood
in order to preserve the multitudes of the world.
Our peace has been concluded;
let it begin from this year!
In the sixth year of the latter part of the emperor's reign, in the winter,
the Xiong-nu invaded the province of Shang with a force of thirty thousand men,
and the Yun-zhong province with the same number.
In order to defend the empire against the barbarians the emperor appointed the palace counselor Ling Mian as general of carriage and cavalry
and sent him to guard the pass at Flying Fox;
the former prime minister of Chu, Su-yi, he made a general
and sent to guard the Ju-zhu Pass;
General Zhang Wu was ordered to garrison Bei-di;
the governor of He-nei, Zhou Ya-fu, was made a general
and ordered to Xi-niu;
the director of the imperial clan Liu Li was made a general
and sent to the Ba River;
and the marquis of Zhu-zi, Xu Li, was made a general and sent to garrison Ji-men.
After a few month
the barbarians withdrew
and the armies were recalled.
The empire was afflicted by drought
and locusts.
The emperor showed his mercy
by ordering the feudal lords not to sent their usual offerings of tribute,
relaxing the laws which prohibited the use of the natural resources of mountains and lakes,
economizing on the imperial robes, carriages, dogs, and horses,
reducing the number of palace attendants and officials,
and opening the storehouses and granaries in order to relieve the sufferings of the poor.
He also allowed the people to buy and sell noble ranks.
It had now been twenty-three years
since Emperor Wen the Filial first arrived from Dai to take the throne.
In that time he had made no move to increase the size of the palaces or halls, the parks or enclosures, or the number of dogs and horses, vestments and carriages.
Whenever some practice proved harmful,
he immediately abandoned it in order to insure benefit to the people.
Once the emperor thought of constructing an open terrace
and summoned artisans to discuss the matter.
When they informed him that it would cost a hundred catties of gold,
he replied,
"A hundred catties of gold is as much as the wealth of ten families of moderate means!
Since I inherited the palaces of the former emperors
I have constantly been afraid that I might dishonor them.
What business would I have in building such a terrace?"
Hsiao Ching Huang-ti (The Filial and Lumious August Emperor or The Filial Emperor Ching, r. 156-141 B.C.)
was a middle son of Hsiao Wen[-ti] (the Filial and cultured emperor Wen).
His mother was Tou T'ai -hou (Empress Dowager Tou).
At the time Hsiao Wen[-ti] was in Tai,
his former queen had three sons.
When Tou T'ai-hou gained favor,
the former queen died,
and then the former queen's three sons died one after the other.
For these reasons, Hsiao Ching[-ti] was able to be established [as Heir].
On the yi-mao day of the fourth month of the first year (20 May 156 B.C.), [the Emperor] granted
an amnesty throughout the world.
On the yi-ssu day (8 May 156 B.C.)
he granted the commoners an increase of one rank.
In the fifth month (27 may-24 June)
he exempted one half of the land tax.
For Hsiao Wen-[ti] he erected the T'ai-tsung Miao (Grand Patriarch Temple).
He ordered that the assembled ministers need not come to court to congratulate [him].
The Hsiung-nu entered Tai,
and he agreed with a martial alliance.
In the spring of the second year (155 B.C.),
he enfeoffed Hsi, the grandson of the former Minister of State, Hsiao Ho, as the Marquis of Wu-ling.
Young men twenty years old registrered [for conscription].
On the jen-wu day of the fourth month (9June 155 B.C.),
the Hsiao Wen T'ai-hou (Empress Dowager of the Filial and Cultured [Emperor]) passed away.
The kings of Kuang-ch'uan and Ch'ang-sha both went to their states.
Chancellor Shen-t'u Chia epired.
In the eighth month
he made Grand Master of the Imperial Scribes T'ao Ch'ing, the Marquis of K'ai-feng, the Chancellor.
A comet appeared in the northeast.
In the autumn
hail fell in Heng-shan,
the large ones [hailstones] measured five ts'un,
the deep ones [penetrating to] two ch'ih.
Mars moved in retrograde
and guarded the North Star.
The moon appeared in the vicinity of the North Star.
Sui Hsing (Jupiter) retrograded amid the constellation
T'ien-t'ing (Heaven's Court). [The Emperor ]established Nan-ling (Southern Mausoleum) and Tui-hsü of Nei-shih as counties.
On the yi-ssu day of the first month of the third year (27 February 154 B.C.), [the Emperor] granted
an amnesty throughout the world.
An elongated star appeared in the west.
Heavenly fire burned the walls and chambers of the Great Hall in the Eastern Palace in Lo-yang.

[Liu] P'i, the King of Wu; [Liu] Wu, the King Ch'u; [Liu] Sui, King of Chao; [Liu} Ang, the King of Chiao-hsi; [Liu] Pi-kuang, the King of Chi-nan, [Liu] Hsien, the King of Tzu-ch'uan; and [Liu) Hsiung-ch'ü, the King of Chiao-tu revolted
and sent out troops heading west.
The Son of Heaven, for them, executed Ch'ao Ts'o
and sent Yü Ang to inform and instruct them;
they did not stop,
moving west and besieging Liang.
The Soverein thereupon sent Commander in Chief Tou Ying (d.131 B.C.) and the Grand Commandant Chou Ya-fu (d.143 B.C.) to lead troops to execute them.
On the yi-hai day of the sixth month (27 July 154 B.C.),
[the Emperor] pardoned the troops that had fled and Yi, the son of King Yüan of Ch'u, and othes who had participated in plotting rebellion.
He enfeoffed the Commander in Chief Tou Ying as the Marquis of Wei-chi.
He extablished the son of King Yüan of Ch'u, [Liu] Li, the Marquis of P'ing-lu, as the King of Ch'u.
[The Empeor] enthroned the imperial son [Liu] Tuan as the King of Chiao-hsi
and his son [Liu] Sheng as the King of Chung-shan.
He transferred [Liu} Chih, the King of Chi-pei, to be the King of Tzu-ch'uan;
[Liu] Yü, the King of Huai-yang, the be the King of Lu;
and [Liu] Fei, King of Ju-nan,as the King of Chiang-tu.
[Liu] Chiang-lu, the King of Ch'i, and [Liu] Chia, the King of Yen both passed on.
In the summer of the fourth year (153 B.C.)
[the Emperor] established the Heir.
He enthroned the imperial son [Liu] Ch'e as King of Chiao-tung.
On the chia-hsü day of the sixth month (20 July 153 B.C.),
[the Emperor] granted an amnesty throughout the world.
In the intercalary month after the ninth month (18 October-16 November 152 B.C.),
[the Emperor] changed Yi-yang to Yang-ling.
He reestablished the fords and passes,
and the use of travel permits for exit and entry.
In the winter
[the Emperor] made the State of Chao into Han-tan Commandery.
In the third month of the fifth year (12 April to 11 May 152 B.C.)
the Yang-ling (Yang Mausoleum) and the bridge over the Wei River were under construction.
In the fifth month (11 June to 10 July 152 B.C.)
[the Emperor] enlisted [people] to move to Yang-ling,
providing 200,000 cash [for the move].
In Chiang-tu a squall came in from the west,
destroying twelve chang of the city wall.
On the ting-mao day (8 July 152 B.C.),
[the Emperor] enfeoffed [Ch'en] Chiao, the son of the Elder Princess, as the Marquis of Lung-lü.
He transferred the King of Kuang-ch'üan to be the King of Chao.
[the Emperor] enfeoffed the Capital Commandant [Wei] Wan as Marquis of Chien-ling;
[Ch'eng] Chia, Chancellor of Chiang-tu, as Marquis of Chien-p'ing;
Hun-yeh, the Governor of Lung-hsi, as the Marquis of P'ing-ch'ü;
[Su] Chia (d.147), Chancellor of Chao, as the Marquis of Chiang-ling; and the former General [Luan] Pu as the Marquis of Shu.
The kings of Liang and Ch'u both passed on.
In the intercalary month
after the ninth month,
they cut trees along the Speedway
to shore up Lan-ch'ih (Orchid lake).
In the winter of the seventh year,
[the Emperor] removed Heir Li and made him the King of Lin-chiang.
On the last day of the eleventh month (22 January 150 B.C),
there was a solar eclipse.
In the Spring
the [Emperor] dismissed consript-laborers who were building Yang-ling.
Chancellor [Tao] Ch'ing was dismissed.
In the second month, on the yi-ssu day (7 April 150 B.C.),
he made Chou Ya-fu, the Grand Commandant, and the marquis of Tiao, the Chancellor.
On the yi-ssu day of the fourth month (6 June 150 B.C.),
he established the Queen Dowager of Chiao-tung as the Huang Hou (August Empress).
On the ting-ssu day (18 June 150 B.C.),
he set up th King of Chiao-tung as the heir.
His praenomen was Ch'e.
In the first year of the Middle Reign (150-149 B.C.),
[the Emperor] enfeoffed [Chou] P'ing,

the grandson of the former Grand master of the Imperial Scribes, Chou K'o, as the Marquis of Sheng, and [Chou] Tso-ch'e, the grandson of the former Grand Master of the Imperial Scribes, Chou Ch'ang, as the Marquis of An-yang.
In the second month of the second year of the Middle Reign (20 march- 17 April 148 B.C.),
the Hsiung-nu entered Yen,
and as a result there was no martial-alliance.
In the third month (18 April-17 May 148 B.C.),
[the Emperor] summoned the King of Lin-chang to kom to [the capital];
he then died shorty after in the office of the Capital Commandant.
In the summer,
In the summer,
[the Emperor] enthroned the Imperial Son [Liu] Yüeh as the King of Kuang-ch'uan, and his son [Liu] Chi as the King of Chiao-tun.
He enfeoffed four marquises.
On the chia-hsü day of the ninth month (22 October 148 B.C.),
the sun eclipsed.
In the winter of the third year of the Middle Reign,
[the Emperor] abolished the Palace Assistant Secretaries among the feudal lords.
In the Spring,
two kings of the Hsiung-nu led their followers in to surrender,
and they were both enfeoffed as ranking marquises. [The Emperor[ enthroned the Imperial Son [Liu] Fang ch'eng as the King of Ch'ing-ho.
In the third month (18 April-17 May B.C.),
a comet appeared in the northwest.
There was a plague of locusts.
In the autumn.
he pardoned the conscript-laborers building Yang-ling.
In the summer of the fifth year (145 B.C.) of the Middle Reign,
he enthroned imperial Son, [Liu] Shun, as the King of Ch'ang-shan.
[The Emperor] enfeoffed ten marquises.
On ting-ssu day of the sixth month (21 July 145 B.C.),
[the Emperor] granted an amnesty throughout the world
and bestowed an increase of one rank.
There were heavy rains in the world.
He changed the title of chancellors of the feudal lords to prime ministers.
In the autumn
the earth quaked.
On the chi-mao day of the second month of the sixth year of the Middle Reign (9 April 144 B.C.),
[the Emperor] favored Yung with a visit,
performing the Chiao (Suburban) Sacrifice to the Five Emperors.
In third month
there was a hailstorm.
In the fourth month (14 May-12 June 144 B.C.),
King Hsiao of Liang, King Kung of Ch'eng -yang, and the King of Ju-nan all passed on.
[The Emperor] enthroned [Liu] Ming, the son of King Hsiao of Liang, as the King of Chi-ch'uan;
[King Hsiao's] son [Liu] P'eng-li as the King of Chi-tung;
[Hsiao's] son [Liu] Ting as the King of Shan-yang;
and [Hsiao's] son [Liu] Pu-shih as the King of Chi-yin.
Liang was divided into five.
He enfeoffed four marquises.
He changed the title of Commandant of Justice to Grand Judge,
Privy Treasurer of Architecture to Court Architect,
Palace Commandant over the Nobility to Capital Commandant,
Supervisor of the Household of the Ch'ang-hsin Palace to Privy Treasurer for the Ch'ang-hsin Palace, .
Empress's Usher to Grand Prolonger of Autumn,
Grand Usher to Usher,
Upholder of Ceremonies to Grand Master of Ceremonies,
Director of Guests to Grand usher,
and Clerk of the Capital for Directing Grain to Minister of Agriculture.
[Officials of the] Grand Inner Palace Office became [a rank of] 2,000 shih,
and a left and right inner official were established,
belonging to the Grand Inner Palace Office.
On the hsin-hai day of the seventh month ( 8 September 144 B.C.), .
there was a solar eclipse
In the eighth month (9 September - 8 October 144 B.C.)
the Hsiung-nu entered Shang-chün.
During the winter of the first year of the Later Reign,
[the Emperor] changed the title of Palace Grand Masters to commondant of the Guards.
On the tin-yu day of the third month (22 April 143 B.C.),
he granted an amnesty throughout the world
and bestowed an increase of one rank.
[Officials] of 2,000 shih and prime ministers of various lords were given the rank of Right Chief of Staff.
On the fourth month (4 May- 1 June 143 B.C.)
there was a great bacchanal.
On the ping-hsü day of the fifth month (10 June 143 B.C.),
the earth quaked,
and during the morning meal there was an aftershock.
The earth quaked for twento-two days in Shang-yung,
destroying the city walls and ramparts.
On the yi-ssu day of the seventh month (28 August 143 B.C.),
there was a solar eclipse.
Chancellor Liu She was dismissed.
On the jen-ch'en day of the eight month
[the Emperor] made Grand Master of the Imperial Scribes, [Wei] Wan, Chancellor
and enfeoffed him as the Marquis of Chien-ling.
During the first month of the second year of the Later Reign (23 February to 24 March B.C.),
the earth quaked three times in one day.
General Chih attacked the Hsiung-nu.
There was a five-day bacchanal.
[The Emperor] ordered the Scribes of the Capital and the commanderies not to feed grain to horses,
[otherwise] they [the hirses] would have to be presented to the local officials.
He ordered the convict- laborers to be clothed in seven-hemp cloth
and the cessation of using horses to pound grain.
Because the harvest did not measure up,
he prohibited all in the world from eating beyond what they would harvest in a season.
He reduced the number of ranking marquises [in the capital] and sent them to [their] states.
In the third month (23 April to 23 May 142 B.C.),
the hsiung-nu entered Yen-men.
In the tenth month (26 Nov. to 25 Dec. 142 B.C.),
the fields of Ch'ang-ling were rented out.
There was a great drought.
In the kingdom of Heng-shan, and in Ho-tung and Yün-chung commanderies, the people suffered epidemics.
In the tenth month of the third year of the Later Reign (16 November-14 December 141 b.C.),
the sun and the moon were both red for five days.
On the last day of the twelfth month (11 February 141 B.C.),
it thundered.
The sun appeared purple.
Five planets moved in retrograde and guarded the constellation of t'ai-wei.
The moon passed through the center of the constellation T'ien-t'ing. Heaven's Court.
On the chia-yin day of the first month (28 February 141 B.C.),
the August heir was capped.
On the chia-tzu day (9 March 141 B.C.),
the Hsiao Ching Huang-ti (The Filial and Lumious August Emperor) passed away.
In his testamentary edict he bestowed an increase of one rank to the noble kings and on down to heirs of fathers among the common people,
and one hundred cash to all households in the world.
The palace women were sent out to return to their homes,
with no [service] to be required again.
The heir ascended the throne,
he became Hsiao Wu Huang-ti (The Filial and Martial August Emperor).
In the third month (11 April- 10 May 141 B.C.),
he enfeoffed the younger half-brothers of the Huang T'ai-hou (August Empress Dowager), [T'ien Fen], as Marquis of Wu-an,
and [Tien] Sheng, as Marquis of Chou-yang.
[Ching-ti] was interred at Yang-ling.
His Honor the Grand Scribe says,
"When the Han arose,
Hsiao Wen[-ti] spread great virtue
and the world cherished peace [that resulted].
By the time of Hsiao Ching[-ti],
there was no further worry about [those lords] of different cognomens.
Yet Ch'ao Ts'o pared and stripped away the [fiefs of the] feudal lords,
finally causing the Seven Kingdoms to all rise up,
join in alliance, and move toward the western regions together.
This was because the feudallords were too vigourous,
and because Ts'o in dealing with them was not [suffiently] deliberate.
When Chu-fu Yen (d.127 B.C.) [later] spoke on this,
the feudal lords were weakened,
and finally pacified.
Does not the key to peace or crises
lie in planning?
Hsiao Wu Huang-ti (The Filial and Martial August Emperor, 156-86 B.C., r. 140-87 B.C.)
was a middle son of Hsiao Ching [-ti] ( The filial and Luminous [Emperor].
His mother was called Wang T'ai-hou (Empress Dowager Wang).
In fourth year of (Emperor) Hsiao Ching (153 B.C).,
as an imperial son he became King of Chaio-tung.
In the seventh year of Hsiao Ching[-ti] (150 B.C.),
the Heir, Li, was deposed to become King of Lin-chiang,
and the King of Chiao-tung was made Heir.
Hsiao ching (-ti) passed away in his sixtieenth year (141 B.C.)
and the Heir ascended the throne
as the Hsiao Wu Huang-ti.
When Hsiao Wu Huang-ti first ascended the throne,
he was particularly respectful of sacrifices to ghosts and spirits.
In his first year (140 B.C.),
it was already more than sixty years since the Han arose
and the world was orderly and at peace;
the civil officials all looked to the Son of Heaven to conduct the Feng and Shan sacrifices and to change the primes and the standards.
The sovereign inclined toward the Confucian art of politics
and summoned the Worthy and the Good,
so that Chao Wan (d.139 B.C.), Wang Tsang (d.139 B.C.) and others became honorable officials and ministers by virtue of their letters and learning.
[The emperor] wished them to deliberate about how in ancient times a Ming T'ang (Hall of Light) was erected south of the city wall
in which to hold audences with the feudal lords.

They drafted plans to conduct tours of inspection, to hold the Feng and Shan sacrifices, and to change the calendar and the colors of court vestments and vehicles, [but ] the plans were not completed.
It happened that the Empress Dowager Tou, who was studying the Huang-Lao teachings
and did not like the political arts of the Confucians,
sent men to secretly gather information on embezzlement by Chao Wan and the rest.
Chao Wan and Wang Tsang were summoned and investigated.
Chao Wan and Wang Tsang committed suicide,
and all the initiatives they undertook were anbandoned.
Six years later (135 B.C.),
Empress Dowager Tou passed away.
The following year (134 B.C.),
the Sovereign summoned to court Kung-sun Hung (ca.200-121 B.C.) and other scholars of letters and learning.
The next year (133 B.C),
the Sovereign for the first time traveled to Yung
to conduct the Chiao (Surburban) Sacrifice at the Wu Chih (Five Altars);
after this the Chiao Sacrifice was regularly performed every three years.
Around this time the Sovereign also sought out the Shen Chün (The Spirit Mistress )
and lodged her in the T'i shih Kuan (Ms.T'i's Tower) in the middle of the Shang-lin (Sovereign's Forest) Preserve.
The Shen Chün
was a woman of Ch'ang-ling
who [died of] anguish and grief over her [infant] son's death,
for this reason, she appeared in spirit form to her sister-in law,
Yüan-jo. Yüan-jo sacrified to the spirit in her home
and large numbers of people came to take part.
P'ing-yüan Chün (Mistress P'ing-yüan) also went there to sacrifice [to the spirit];
after this her descendants thereby became honored and distinguished.
When Wu-ti ascended the throne he treated the Shen Chün to sumptuous rites
and relocated her shrine within the imperial hunting preserve.
The spirit's words could be heard,
but her form could not be seen.

At this time Li Shao-chün also had an audience with the Sovereign; by means of [his skills in] sacrificing to the Tzu'u Tsao (God of the Furnace), dietarye practices, and methods for retarding old age,
the Sovereign accorded him great respect.
Li Shao-chün
had formerly been a houseman of the marquis of Shen-tse who recommended him [to the emperor] as a magician.
He kept his age and birthplace a secret,
always claiming to be seventy [years old],
capable of manipulating spirits,
and retarding old age.
He traveled among the courts of the feudal lords by virtue of his [magical] methods.
He had no wife or children.
On hearing he was able to manipulate spirits, and achieve immortality,
people lavished even more gifts on him,
so that he wasalways more than amply provided with money, silk clothing, and food.
People all thought that he managed no productive enterprises and yet was abundantly supplied with everything,
and not knowing where he was from,
people's faith in him increased all the more,
and they competed to serve him.
Shao-chün derived his livelihood from his proficiency in [magical] methods,
and he was especially skillful in making artful statements that later proved uncannily accurate.
He once accompanied the Marquis of Wu-an drinking,
among the company there was an old man of over ninety.
Shao-chün then spoke about a place where he had wandered and practiced achery with the old man's grandfather.
The old man had traveled with his grandfather as a boy
recognized the place;
the whole company was completely amazed.
[Another time] Shao-chün appeared before the Sovereign
and the Sovereign asked him (Ba)
about an ancient bronze vessel the Sovereign possessed. (Ab)
Shao-chün said:
"Duke Huan of Ch'i (r.685-643 B.C.) displayed this vessel in the Po-ch'in [T'ai] (Cypress Chamber [Terrace] in his tenth year (676 B.C.).
Shortly after, when the inscription was examined,
the bronze indeed proved to be Duke Huan of Ch'i's.
The whole palace was astonished
and took Shao-chün to be a spirit,
someone who had lived hundreds of years.
Li Shao-chün told the Sovereign:
"If you sacrifice to the Furnace, you will summon the spirits;
once you summon the spirits, cinnabar grains can be transformed into yellow gold;
the yellow gold once made, if you fashion drinking and eating utensils from it, you can prolong your life;
with prolonged life you can visit the immortals who live on the [isles of] P'eng lai in the middle of the sea;
on seeing them, by means of performing the Feng and Shan sacrifices you will never die.
This is what the Huang-ti (The Yellow Emperor) did.
"Your servant once wandered across the sea
and saw master An-chi
who fed me jujubes
as big as melons.
The immortal Master An-ch'i
made it to [the isles of] P'eng-lai.
When it suits him, he reveals himself.
otherwise he stays hidden."
At this, the Son of heaven began to sacrifice in person to the God of the furnace.
he also sent practitioners of [magical] methods to sea to search for P'eng-lai, master An-ch'i, and the rest,
and had attempts made to transform cinnabar grains and medicinal concoctions into yellow gold.
After some time,
Li Shao-chün fell ill and died.
The Son of Heaven believed that he had transformed himself [into an immortal] an did not die,
so he had the Scribe from Huang and Ch'ui, K'uan-shu, carry on Li's [magical] methods.
In the search for P'eng-lai and Master An-ch'i, they were unable to find anything,
but on the seacoast of Yen and Ch'i many strange and outlandish imitators imitated [Li],
one after another expounding on spiritual matters.
A man from Po by the name of Miu Chi submitted a memorial on the methods of sacrifice to the T'ai-yi (Grand Unity),
saying:
"The Grand Unity is the highest heavily spirit,
and the Grand Unity's assistants are called the Wu Ti (Five Emperors).
"In ancient times the Son of Heaven sacrificed to the Grand Unity every spring and autumn in the southeastern suburbs,
employing the T'ai-lao
for seven days.
An altar was constructed that was open to the ghost roads of the eight directions."
"At this, The Son of Heaven ordered Grand Supplicator to establish such shrines in the southeastern suburbs of Ch'ang-an,
where sacrifices were regularly offered according to the methods of [Miu] Chi.
Thereafter, someone [else] submitted a mmemorial to the throne
saying: "In ancient times, once every three years the Son of Heaven would employ a complete set of T'ai-lao Sacrifices to sacrifice to the spirits of the San-yi (Three Unitities):
"the T'en-yi (Heavenly Unity),
the Ti-yi (Earthly Unity),
and the T'ai-Yi (Grand Unity)."
"The Son of Heaven consented to this
and ordered the Grand Supplicator to lead the sacrifices to them on [Miu] Chi's altar to the Grand Unity
according to this method.
"Afterward,someone again submitted a memorial to the throne
saying: "in ancient times the Son of Heaven regularly conducted Exorcistic Sacrifices in spring and autumn;
in sacrificing to the Huan-ti he employed an owl and a "broken mirror";
to Ming Yang (Dark Ram) he employed a sheep;
in sacrificing to Ma Hsing (Horse Traveler) he employed a black stallion;
to the Grand Unity, the Kao-shan Shan-chün (Mountain Lord og Mount Kao), and Ti Chang (Earth Elder) he employed an ox;
to Wu-yi Chün (The Lord of Wu-yi) he employed dried fish;
and to the Yin Yang Shih-che (The envoys of Yin and Yang) he employed an ox."
The officials in charge of sacrifices were ordered to lead [rites] according to these methods,
sacrificing alongside [Miu] Ch'is altar to the Grand Unity.
"After this
there were white deer in the Son of Heaven's [game] peserve.
He had their hides made into a kind of currency
to make known this auspicious portent
and initiated the minting of a white metal coinage.
"The following year (123 B.C.),
during the Chiao Sacrifice at Yung,
a one-honored animal was captured
which looked like a Piao deer.
The authorities concerned said:
"Your Majesty solemny and reverently carried out the Chiao Sacrifice
and the Supreme Deity has repaid your offerings
by bestowing this one-horned animal;
probably this is a unicorn."
At this, the emperor offered it up at the five Altars,
and added a burnt offering of an ox at each.
He bestowed on each of the feudal lords white-metal [coins]
to allude to the auspicions sign in harmony with Heaven and Earth.
At this time, the King of Chi-pei, thinking the Son of Heaven
enfeoffed the King of Ch'ang-shan committed an offense and was banished,
The Son of Heaven accepted them
and compensated with other counties in exchange.
When the King of Ch'ang-shan committed and offense and
was banished,
the Son of Heaven enfeoffed the King's younger brother at Chen-ting
to continue the sacrifices to the former kings [of Ch'ang-shan],
and then he made Ch'ang-shan into a commandery.
Therefore, all the Wu Yüeh (Five Sacred Peaks) were situated in commanderies [under the direct control] of the Son of Heaven.
The following year (122 B.C.),
a native of Ch'i, Shao Weng (The Youthful Gaffer), through his [magical] methods with ghosts and spirits, gained an audience with the Sovereign.
The Sovereign had a favorite, Lady Wang,
who had expired.
It was said that Shao Weng used his [magical] methods and techniques to summon her spectral apparation and that of the Ghost of the Furnace at night,
while the Son of Heaven watched them at a distance from among the curtains.
At this, the Emperor appointed Shao Weng as General of Accomplished Letters
and lavishly rewarded him,
treating him with the curtesy due an imperial guest.
[The General of ] accomplished Letters said:
"Inasmuch as your Majesy desires to communicate with the spirits,
if the furnishings of the palace and apartments as well as your own vestments are not patterned after the spirits,
they will not come."
The [the Emperor had [five] carriages made decorated with cloud-emanation [patterns]
each driven on the day its power was in the ascendancy, to ward off malevolent ghosts.
He also built a terraced chamber
in the center of the Kan-ch'üan King (Sweet Palace),
which was decorated with images of Heaven, Earth, the Grand Unity, and all the other spirits,
and there he placed the sacrificial [offering] vessels to attract the spirits of Heaven.
After more than a year,
his [magical] methods grew weaker
and the spirits failed to come,
so he wrote something on silk and fed it to an ox.
Then, feigning ignorance,
he said there was something extraordinary in the ox's belly.
The ox was slaughtered, examined,
and the document retrieved.
The document's wording was utterly bizarre
and the Son of Heaven became suspicious about it.
Someone recognized the calligraphy.
Having questioned the man,
it was indeed [determined to be] a forged document.
At this, the General of Accomplished Letters was executed and the affair was hushed up.
After this buildings like the Po-liang [T'ai] (Cypress Beams [Terrace] were also built with bronze pillars and statues of immortals in whose upraised palms dew was collected.
The year after [the General of] Accomplished Letters died (118 B.C.),
the Son of Heaven fell gravely ill at Ting Hu (Tripod Lake);
he caused all the shamanesses and physicians to come,
[but] he did not improve.
[Earlier,] Fa Ken of Yu-shui had said:
"In Shang-chün [Commandery] there is a shamaness
who fell ill and ghosts descended upon her.
The Sovereign summoned her and sacrificed to her in the Kan-ch'üan Palace.
When he became ill [himself],
he sent someone to ask the Spirit mistress [through the shamaness],
who responded:
"The Son of Heaven must not worry about this illness;
when the illness has improved slightly,
he should make an effort to join me in Kan-ch'üan [Palace]."
At this the Emperor's illness improved slightly;
he then favored Kan-ch'üan with his presence,
and his sickness really was completely cured.
He granted a general amnesty throughout the world
and established the Shou Kung (Palace of Longevity) for the Spirit Mistress.
Among those most honored by the Spirit Mistress was the T'ai-yi (Grand Unity),
whose assistants were called Ta Chin (Grand Prohibiter), Ssu Ming (Arbiter of Fate), and the like,
and who all accompanied her.
They could not be seen,
but their voices could be heard;
they sounded like human speech.
Sometimes they departed and sometimes they came,
and when they came it was like the soughing of the wind.
Dwelling among the curtains of the chamber,
they sometimes spoke in the daytime,
but usually by night.
The Son of Heaven would first perform the purgation rites
and only thereafter enter [the chamber];
relying on the shamaness
to act as host;
they should partake of the food and drink, whatever they wanted to say being relayed [through the shamaness].
The Emperor further established the Shou Kung and the Pei-kung (North Palace)
and had feathered banners unfurled
and ritual paraphernalia set out
to perform rites for the Spirit Mistriss.
Whatever the Spirit Mistress said
the Sovereigh would have someone write down,
and [these writings] he named Hua fa (Record of mantic Arts).
What the spirit spoke about
was just common knowledge
and nothing out out of the ordinary,
and only the Son of Heaven was pleased with it.
This business was kept secret, however,
and no one knew about it at the time.
Three years later(114 B.C.),
the authorities concerned said that in originating [reign periods] it would be appropriate to name them after auspicious signs from Heaven,
and it was not appropriate to enumerate "first", an "second," [etc.].
The first origination should be called Chien-yüan (Establishing the Originations);
the second origination named for the comet, should be called Yüan-kuang (The Origination in Resplendence);
the third origination (122 B.C.), bcause during the Chiao Sacrifice a one-horned animal was captured, should be called Yüan-shou (The Origination of Hunt)
In the winter of the following year (113 B.C),
having performed the Chiao Sacrifice at Yung, the Son of Heaven had [his officials]
deliberate about it:
"Now We have personally performed the Chia Sacrifice to the Supreme Deity,
but have not made an offering to the Hou-t'u (Mother Earth) and,
according to the rites, this is anappropriate."
The authorities concerned deliberated with the Prefect of the Grand Scribes, the officials in charge of sacrifices, K'uan -shu and others:
"For Heaven and Earth the sacrifial oxen has horns the size of a silkworm cocoon or a chestnut.
Now if your Majesty sacrifices in person to Mother Earth,
it would be appropriate to built Five Altars on a round hillock in the middle of a marshy place
and on each altar there should be a set of yellow-calf T'ai-lao sacrifices."
When the sacifices are over, the victims should be completely buried.
The vestments of those in attendance at the sacrifice should exalt the color yellow."
At this the Son of Heaven proceeded to the east
where he first established sacrifices to Mother Earth on a mound at Fen-yin (South Bank of the Fen),
according to the deliberations of K'uan-shu and the others.
The sovereign personally performed the prostrations at the Wang (Sacrifice from Afar),
as in the rites for the Suppreme Deity.
After the rites were concluded
the Son of Heaven returned by the way of Hsing-yang.
On the way he passed by Lo-yang
where he issued a decree stating:
"The [line of the] Three Dynasties has long been severed,
their remoteness has made its continuation difficult.
Let an area of thirty li [on one side] be taken to enfief the descendant of Chou as the Lord of the Chou Viscount and Garons,
so that he might perform the sacrifices to the former kings [his ancestors] there."
In this year,
the Son of Heaven for the first time traveled on a tour of inspection through comanderies and counties,
proceeding by degrees toward Mount Tai.
In this [same] spring,
the Marquis of Lo-ch'eng submitted a memorial to the throne which spoke of Luan Ta.
Luan Ta
was a Man of the Palace [in the service of the King] of Chiao-tung
who had formerly had the same teacher as the General of Accomplished Letters.
Shorly thereafter, he became Master of Medical Methods to King [K'ang] of Chiao-tung.
The older sister of the Marquis of Lo-ch'eng had become King K'ang's queen,
but was childless.
When King K'ang died,
the son of another consort was enthroned as King.
But King K'ang's queen had acted licentiously
and could not get along with the king,
each threatening the other with legal action.
King K'ang's queen, on hearing that [the General of] Accomplished Letters [Shao Weng] had already died,
and wishing to ingratiate herself with the Sovereign,
dispatched Luan Ta through the good offices of the Marquis of Lo-ch'eng [her brother] to seek an audience to expound on his [magical] methods.
After having executed [the General of] Accomplished Letters,
the Son of Heaven felt remorse over his premature death
and regretted that his methods had not been exhaustively tried;
when Luan Ta obtained an audience
the Emperor was delighted.
[Luan] Ta was a man who was tall and handsome,
capable of speaking about innumerable [magical] methods and strategems,
who ventured to speak expansively,
and handled [everything] without hesitation.
[Luan] Ta expansively said:
"Your servant once ventured into the middle of the sea
and saw An-ch'i, Hsien-men [Kao] and the other [immortals].
But they considered me a humble commoner
and would not take your servant into their confidence.
Moreover, because they considered King K'ang to be no more than a feudal lord,
he was unworthy to receive their [magical] methods.
Your servant spoke of this often to King K'ang,
but he still did not make use of me.
"Your servant's master said:
'Yellow gold can be made;
the breaches in the Ho dikes can be plugged;
the drug of immortality can be obtained,
and immortals may be summoned.'
[But] your servant feared he would meet the same fate as Shao Weng,
so we practitioners of [magical] methods all kept our peace.
How dare I speak of my methods!"
The Sovereign replied,
"[The General of] Accomplished Letters [Lao Weng] merely died from eating horse's liver.
If you are truly able to carry on his [magical] methods,
what could I possibly begrudge you?"
[Luan] Ta said:
"Your servant's masters seek nothing of men,
it is men who seek of them.
If Your Majesty is determined to invite them here,
then ennoble your envoys,
make them imperial relatives,
treat them with the courtesy due guests,
and do not humble them.
Let your envoys each hang their seals of office from their girdles,
and then you can send them to converse with spiritual beings.
Whenever the spiritual beings will accede or not is still uncertain,
but if you bestow high honors on your envoys,
then they may be induced to come."
At this the Sovereign first had [Luan Ta] make chess pieces fight to verify his minor [magical] methods;
the chess pieces threw themselves against each other of their own accord.
At this time the Sovereign was distressed about the breaches in the Ho dikes
and the failure to make yellow gold.
So he appointed [Luan] Ta the rank of General of the Five Benefits.
In just over one month,
Luan Ta acquired four bronze seals:
he wore on his girdle those of General of Heavenly Practitioners, General of Earthly Practitioners, General Grand Communicator, and General of the Heavenly Way.
The Emperor issued an edict to the [Grand Master of the] Imperial Scribes:
"Long ago, Yü dredged the Nine Chiang
and determined the courses of the Four Streams.
Recently, the Ho has overflowed its banks onto the plain
and the corvee laborers at the dikes have not rested.
Having ruled the world for twenty-eight years,
it seems Heaven has sent Us this practioner, [Luan] Ta, who is able to comprend it.
Hexagram Ch'ien "The Creative" speaks of a 'flying dragon'
and there is 'the wild goosedraws near the slope,'
whose import would seem to correspond to this situation.
Let the General of Earthly Practitioners, [Luan] Ta, be enfeoffed with two thousand households as Marquis of Lo-t'ung.
The Emperor bestowed on him an official residence of a full marquis
and thousand servant -boys,
let him ride in an equipage from among the emperor's unwanted carriages and horses, and [bestowed] hangings, draperies, utensils, and implements with which to fill his household.
Moreover, [the Emperor] gave him in marriage [his daughter] the elder
granted him [a dowry of] ten thousand chin of gold,
and changed the name of her manor [so that] she was called Princess of Tang-li (The Princess Who Was Matched to [Five] Benefits)."
The Son of Heaven went in person to the General of the Five Benefit's residence,
and the envoys sent to present greetings and inquire after his needs
formed an unbroken stream on the roads.
From the Grand Princess to generals and ministers on down,
all feted him [Luan Ta] in their homes
and presented him gifts.
At this, the Son of Heaven further had a jade seal engraved with the inscription "General of the Heavenly Way".
He sent an envoy wearing feather clothes
who at night stood on white rushes,
while the General of the Five Benefits, also wearing feather clothes
and standing on white rushes, received the seal
to show that he [Luan Ta] was not considered a subject [of the emperor].
[Luan Ta] was to hang [the seal of] the T'ien-tao (Heavenly Way) on his girdle
and moreover provide the way to the heavenly spirits for the Son of Heaven.
At this point, [the General of] the Five Benefits regularly sacrificed at his home during the night,
intending to cause the spirits to descend.
The spirits did not arrive, but hundreds of ghosts gathered;
yet [Luan Ta] was quite capable of manipulating them.
After this, he packed for a journey,
and was said to have put to sea off the eastern coast
in search of his master.
A few months after his [first] audience with the Emperor,
[Luan] Ta had hung six seals of office from his girdle
and his preeminence astounded the world.
Along the seacoast between Yen and Ch'i
there was none who did not seize his wrist in his fist and declare himself in possession of secret [magical] methods
capable of attracting spirits and immortals.
In the middle of the sixth month of this summer (113 B.C.),
when the shamaness Chin from Fen-yin was performing a sacrifice to Mother Earth on behalf of the common people at the mound in Wei,
she looked and saw [a place where] the earth was shaped like a hook.
When she dug and looked, she found a tripod.
It was large and quite unlike most others,with inscribed decor,
but lacking a dedicatory inscription.
Marvelling at it,
she told the [local] officials.
The officials informed Sheng, the Grand Administrator of Ho-tung,
who informed [the court].
The Son of Heaven sent an envoy to verify [the matter] and ask the shamaness Chin about finding the tripod to establish that there was no trickery or deception involved.
Then he sacrificed in accordance with the rites.
Going forth to receive the tripod he arrived at Kan-ch'üan,
and taking it with him,
the Sovereign offered it [to Heaven].
On reaching Chung-shan (Middle Mountain)
the weather cleared, it warmed up,
and there was a yellow cloud covering it [the mountain].
There was a deer that passed by
and the Sovereign shot it himself,
taking advantage of this to use it in the sacrifice.
On arriving in Ch'ang-an,
the honorable officials, ministers and grandees all deliberated [among themselves] and requested that the precious tripod be treated with utmost respect.
The Son of Heaven said:
"Recently the Ho has overflowed
and several harvests have not measured up;
for this reason We traveled on a tour of inspection to sacrifice to mother Earth
to pray for the increase of grain on behalf of the people.
This year has been no response by way of an abundant harvest.
Why has this tripod appeared?"
The authorities concerned all said:
"We have heard that long ago when the Ta-ti (The Great Emperor) arose he made one sacred tripod,
the number one symbolizing unified rule
- Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things being completely brought together.
The Huang-ti made three precious tripods
to symbolize Heaven, Earth, and Man.
Yü collected bronze from the nine Provinces
and cast nine tripods.
All of them used the sacred tripods to cook sacrificial offerings to the Supreme Deity, the spirits, and ghosts [of the ancestors].
On encountering a sage ruler the tripods arose;
they were removed to Hsia and Shang.
When the virtue of Chou declined
and the altar to the Earth in Sung was gone,
the tripods sank under water, lay hidden, and finally vanished.
The Laudes says:' From the hall they go to the gate-hous base,
from the sheep they go to the oxen;
there are big tripods and small...
they are not noisy, not clamorous;
that secures the tranquillity of those of a great old age.'
Now when the tripod reached Kan-chüan,
it shone profusely, its dragon patterns scintillating;
the beneficence received is boundless.
In accordance with this [shooting of the deer] on Middle Mountain,
when the yellow-white cloud descended to cover Middle Mountain,
it served as an auspicious sign,just as the wild animals had.
Brought down by your great bow and suite of four arrows,
[the deer] was gathered at the foot of the altar mound
where the grand reward sacrifice [of thanksgiving to the ancestors] was held.
Only one who received the Mandate and ruled as Emperor could know its [Heaven's] intentions and accord his virtue with [Heaven].
It is fitting that the tripod be displayed before the ancestral tablets
and preserved in the Emperor's Court,
to accord with these bright omens."
The imperial decree said:
" So be it."
Those who had gone to sea in search of P'eng-lai
said that the isles were not distant,
and that their inability to reach P'eng-lai was likely due to
their not perceiving the emanations from it.
Then the Sovereign dispatched a specialist in watching for the emanations to attend to its [P'eng-lai's] emanations.
That autumn (113 B.C.),
the Sovereign favored Yung with a visit
and was about to perform the Chiao Sacrifice.
Some said, "The Five Emperors
are but the assistants of the Grand Unity.
It would be appropriate to establish sacrifices to the Grand Unity and for the Sovereign personally to perform the Chiao Sacrifice to it."
The Sovereign harbored doubts about the matter and remained undecided.
A man of Ch'i, Kung-sun Ch'ing, said,
"This year the precious tripod was obtained,
and this winter the solstice falls on hsin-ssu day of the new moon at dawn (24 December 113 B.C.),
just as in the time of the Huang-ti."
Ch'ing possessed a document written on wooden tablets which said,
"The Huang-ti obtained a precious tripod at Yüan-ch'ü
and asked Kuei Yü-ch'ü about it.
[Kuei Yü-]ch'ü replied:
'Your Majesty has obtained the precious and sacred counting sticks;
this very year the winter solstice falls on the chi'yu day of the new moon at dawn,
this according with the cycles of Heaven
which will now end and begin again.'
At that, the Huang-ti, by manipulating the counting sticks,
made a calendar and generally every twenty years the winter solstice once again coincided with the new moon at dawn.
Projecting the calculation ahead twenty times,
for a total of three hundred eighty years,
was when the Huang-ti will become a mortal and ascend to Heaven."
[Kung-sun] Ch'ing wishing to memorise the Emperor went through So Chung,
So Chung, seeing the document was heterodox,
suspected it to be a fabrication
and declined, saying:
"The affair of the precious tripod has already been decided.
What is the point of pursuing the matter?"
[Kung-sun] Ch'ing went through one of the Emperor's favorites to memorialize him.
The Sovereign was greatly pleased
and summond [Kung-sun] Ch'ing for questioning.
The latter replied:
"I received this document from Shen-kung
who has since died."
The Sovereign asked,
"What kind of a man was Shen Kung?"
[Kung-sun] Ch'ing answered:
"Shen Kung
was a man of Ch'i
who, to communicate with master An-ch'i,
received the words of the Huang-ti.
He left no writings;
there is only this document about tripods.
It says, 'The rise of Han ought once again to correspond to the time of the Huang-ti.
The sage ruler of the Han is among the grandsons or great-grandsons of Kao-tsu (The Exalted Ancestor).
The precious tripod will appear and then he will communicate with the spirits
and perform the Feng and Shan sacrifices
Of the seventy-two kings
who performed the Feng and Shan sacrifices, only the Huang-ti was able to climb Mount T'ai to perform the Feng Sacrifice.
Shen Kung said:
The ruler of Han also ought to go up an offer the Feng Sacrifice;
if the Sovereign performs the Feng Sacrifice, he will be able to ascend into Heaven as an immortal.
In the time of the Huang-ti, there were ten thousand feudal lords,
and the sacred spirits receiving Feng Sacrifices amounted to seven thousand.
There were eight famous mountains in the world,
three among the Man and Yi [tribes]
and five in the Central States,
Mount Hua, Mount Shou, [Mount] T'ai-shih (Great Chamber), Mount T'ai, and Mount Tung-lai,
these five mountains, were regularly visited by the Huang-ti commune
with the spirits.
On the one hand, the Huang-ti devoted himself to military campaigns;on the other, [he devoted himself] to studying the immortals.
He was worried that the families of the hundred cognomens criticized his ways,
and so he brougth to judgment and beheaded those who denied the ghosts and spirits.
After over a hundred years had passed he was able to communicate with the spirits.
The Huang-ti performed the Chiao Sacrifice to the Supreme Deity at Yung,
and lodged there for three months.
[Kuei Yü-]ch'ü's designation was Ta-hung (Great Crane),
and when he died he was buried at Yung;
this is the old Hung-chung (Crane Tumulus).
Afterward, the Huang-ti received ten thousand spirit-beings in the Ming T'ing (Court of Light);
this Court of Light
was [nine other than] Kan-ch'uan.
The so called Han-men (Cold Gate)
is just Ku-k'ou (Mouth of the Valley).
The Huang-ti had copper extracted from Mount Shou
and had a tripod cast at the foot of Mount Ching.
When the tripod was finished,
a dragon with whiskers dangling from its chin came down to meet him.
The Huang-ti mounted and rode it;
over seventy of his ministers and palace women followed him and mounted the dragon,
after which the dragon took off.
Those remaining lower-ranking subordinates were not able to get on,
but all clung to the dragon's whiskers.
The dragon's whiskers pulled out,
causing the Huang-ti's bow to fall to the ground.
When the people looked up and saw that the Huang-ti had ascended to Heaven,
they hugged his bow and the dragon's whiskers and wailed.
For these reasons later generations called the place Ting Hu (Tripod Lake),
and his bow Wu Hao (Crow Call)."
At this the Son of Heaven said:
"Ah!
If We could truly be like the Huang-ti,
leaving Our wives and children would be like doffing a slipper!"
Then he appointed [Kung-sun] Ch'ing Attendant
and sent him east to attend to the spirits at [Mount] T'ai-shih (Great Chamber).
The Sovereign then performed the Chiao Sacrifice at Yung;
he reached Lung-hsi,
went west to ascend Mount K'ung,
and then favored Kan-ch'üan with a visit.
He ordered the official in charge of offerings, K'uan-shu, and the others to prepare the altar for sacrifices to the Grand Unity.
The altar was modeled after [Miu] Chi of Po's altar to the Grand Unity,
with three levels.
The altar to the Five Emperors were located below it on all sides,
each in its given direction,
the Huang-ti's to the southwest,
and eight ghost roads were cleared through [to the main altar].
Those [offerings] used for the Grand Unity
were like those at each altar at Yung
with adition of sweet wine, jujubes, dried meat, and the like.
A single long-haired ox was killed to make up the grand set of sacrificial animals,with accompanying sacrificial vessels and stands.
For the Five Emperors, only the [sacrificial offerings] in vessels and stands and sweet wine were presented.
Below this on the ground in the four directions
the hosts of spirit followers together with the Northern Dipper were offered libations and food in succession.
After sacrificing,
the remaining sacrifical meat was all immolated.
The color of this ox was white,
the deer was placed inside it,
and the hog inside the deer,
water being added to stew them.
An ox was used to sacrifice to the sun;
to the moon a sheep or a hog were sacrificed.
The Grand Supplicator and Master of Ceremonies for the Grand Unity wore purple robes decorated with embroidery.
Each of the Five Emperors was accorded his color;
for the sun it was red,
for the moon white.
On the hsin-ssu day of the new moon in the eleventh month (24 December 113 B.C.), at winter solstice,
in the dawn light,
the Son of Heaven first performed the Chiao Sacrifice and a prostration to the Grand Unity.
At dawn he performed the Chao (Morning) Sacrifice to the [rising] sun,
and in the evening the Hsi (Evening) Sacrifice to the moon,
and then bowed.
The invocation accompanying the sacrifice said,
"Heaven has for the first time bestowed upon the August Emperor the precious tripod and sacred counting stalks,
the new moon has once again become the new moon,
ending [the cycle] and beginning again.
The August Emperor respectfully prostrates himself to [Heaven]."
The vestments [used in the rites] exalted yellow,
and the fires of the sacrifice filled the altar,
alongside which were arrayed the ritual vessels for cooking the sacrifices.
The autorities concerned declared, "Above the sacrifice there appeared a light."
The honorable officials and ministers said:"When the August Emperor for the first time presented himself to the Grand Unity during the Chiao Sacrifice at Yün-yang,
the authorities concerned held jade discs and excellent sacrificial victims were presented for the sacrifice.
That night there was beautiful gleam of light,
and at daylight
a yellow emanation rose up to Heaven."
The Grand Scribe, the Official in Charge of Offerings, K'uan-shu, and others said:
"The sacred spirits in their beneficence
bestow auspicious tokens of assistance and prosperity.
It is fitting that because of this there be established in this place of brillant pertents an altar platform to the Grand Unity to make manifest the [auspicious] response.
Let the Grand Supplicator lead sacrifice
from the autumn through the La Festival.
The Son of Heaven should appear at the Chiao Sacrifice once every three years."
That autumn (112 B.C.),
in preparation for a punitive expedition against Nan Yüeh,
the attack was announced in prayers to the Grand Unity.
A banner decorated with images of the sun, moon, Northern Dipper, and rampant dragons
was mounted on a shaft made from the wood of the thorn tree, to symbolize the T'en-yi (Heaven Unity) and its three stars,
vanguard of the Grand Unity.
[The banner] was called Ling-ch'i (The Efficacious Flag).
When one prayed for military success,
the Grand Scribe would hold it aloft and point in the direction of the country to be attacked.
At the same time, the General of the Five Benefits [Luan Ta], who had been sent as an envoy, did not venture to put to sea,
and [instead] went to Mount T'ai to sacrifice.
The Sovereign sent men to follow him surreptitiously and verify [any results];
in fact there was nothing for them to see.
[The General of] the Five Benefits falsely said he had seen his master [beyond the sea],
but his [magical] methods were exhausted,
for the most part having elicted no response.
The Sovereign then executed [the General of the ] Five Benefits.
That winter (111 B.C.),
Kung-sun Ch'ing was waiting on the spirits in Ho-nan,
when atop the city wall of Kou-shih he saw the tracks of an immortal.
There was a creature like a pheasant
walking back and forth on top of the wall.
The Son of Heaven in person favored the Kou-shih city wall with a visit to view the tracks;
he asked [Kung-sun] Ch'ing,
"You wouldn't be imitating Accomplished Letters [Shao Weng] and Five Benefits [Luan Ta], would you?"
[Kung-sun] Ch'ing replied:
"The immortals are not those who seek out the ruler of men;
it is the ruler of men who seeks them.
If this way is not accommodating and patient,
the spirirts will not come.
When I speak of spirit matters
they seem unnatural and exaggerated,
but if one persits for a number of years the spirits can be induced to come."
After this, in anticipation of an imperial visit, each and every commandery and kingdom cleared the roads
and refurbished or built palaces and towers, as well as famous mountain shrines
dedicated to the spirits.
That year (111 B.C.),
after the destruction of Nan Yüeh,
the Sovereign had a favorite subject, Li Yen-nien, who gained audience because of skills in music.
The Sovereign condidered him excellent
and ordered the honorable officials and ministers to deliberate:
"In the sacrifices among the common people there is still the music of instruments and dancing.
Now when the Chiao Sacrifice is performed there is no music.
How can this be appropriate?"
The honorable officials and ministers replied,
"In ancient times, when sacrificing to Heaven and Earth there was always music,
and their spirits could be invoked and accorded the proper rites."
Someone said,
The Tai-ti (Great Emperor) had the Su Nü (White Maiden) play the fifty-string zither,
but it was too melancholy.
The emperor could not bear it;
for this reason he broke the zither [in half] to make a twenty-five string zither."
Therefore,during the thanksgiving offering [for the victory over] Nan Yüeh,
when prayers and sacrifices were offered to the Grand Unity and Mother Earth,
music and dancing were used for the first time.
In addition, choirs of boys were summoned
and from this time on the twenty-five string zither and Hou's harp-zither began to be made.
In winter of the next year (110 B.C.),
the Sovereign deliberated and said,
"In ancient times, the weapons were first stored and the soldiers discharged,
and thereafter the Feng and Shan sacrifices were performed."
Thereupon he made a tour of inspection to the north to Shuo-fang
and drilled over one hundred thousand soldiers.
On returning he sacrificed at the tumulus of the Huang-ti at Mount Ch'iao,
and then discharged the soldiers at Hsü-ju.
The Sovereign said,
"We have heard that the Huang-ti did not die;
now there is this tumulus.
Why is that?"
Someone responded,
"After the Huang-ti became and immortal and ascented to Heaven,
his ministers buried his clothes and hats [there]."
After reaching Kan-ch'uan,
as he was about to conduct the affairs [for the Feng and Shan sacrifices] on Mount T'ai,
a Lei sacrifice was first performed to the Grand Unity.
From the time the precious tripod was obtained,
the Sovereign together with the honorable officials, ministers and various scholars deliberated about [instituting] the Feng and Shan sacrifices.
The Feng and Shan sacrifices had been rarely performed,and had been cut off for a long time;
no one knew their ceremonies and rituals.

The assembled Confusian scholars culled material selected from the Shang shu (Documents of High Antiquity), the Chou kuan (Offices of Chou), and the "Wang Chih" (Kingly Regulations) pertaining to the Wang (From Afar) Sacrifice and the [royal officiant's] shooting of the [Sacrificial]ox.
A man of Ch'i, Master Ting, who was over ninety years old, said:
"The Feng [Sacrifice]
is in accord with an immortal name.
The [First] Emperor of Ch'in was unable to ascend [the mountain]and perform the Feng Sacrifice.
If your Majesty insists on ascending [the mountain],
go up a little and if there is no wind or rain,
then make the ascent and perform the Feng Sacrifice."
At this, the Sovereign ordered the assembled Confucian scholars to practice shooting the [sacrificial] oxen
and to draft the ceremonies for the Feng and Shan sacrifices.
After several years,
the time had come to carry out [these sacrifices].
The Son of Heaven had already paid heed to the words of Kung-sun Ch'ing and the practioners of [magical] methods
about how the Huang-ti and earlier [rulers] had conducted the Feng and Shan [sacrifices];
they all had been able to summon strange creatures and commune with the spirits.
The Emperor desired to imitate the Huang-ti's having been able to contact the spirits, immortals, and gentlemen of P'eng-lai,
to transcend the [mundane] world and compare in virtue to the Chi-huang (Nine August Ones).
Moreover, he selected from the methods of the Confucians to embellish them [the sacrifices].
The assembled Confucian scholars, having been unable to descuss and clarify the affairs to the Feng and Shan rites,
and furthermore constrained by rigid adherence to ancient documents like the Shih (The Odes) and the Shu (The Documents), dared not improvise.
The Sovereign had ritual vessels for the Feng Sacrifice manufactured and showed them to the assembled Confucian scholars;
one of the assembled Confucian scholars said, "These are not the same as in ancient times."
Hsü Yen further added, "The performance of the rites by the various scholars under the Grand Master of Ceremonies is not as good as that of [the state of] Lu."
Chou Pa gathered together [the Confucian scholars] to plan the Feng [and Shan] affairs.
At this, the Sovereign demoted [Hsü] Yen and [Chou] Pa,
dismissed the assembled Confucian scholars, and did not employ them.
In the third month (31 March to 28 April 110 B.C.),
the Emperor proceeded eastward and favored Kou-shih with a visit,
and as prescribed by the rites he ascended the T'ai-shih (Great Chamber) of the Chung-yüeh (Central Sacred Peak).
While at the foot of the mountain the officials in his entourage heard what sounded like the words, " Ten thousand year's longevity!"
They asked those [who had been] above on the mountain about it,
and they had not spoken the words;
[who had remained] below,
and they had not said them.
At this, the Emperor founded a shrine to the T'ai-shih supported by three hundred households [from the foot of the mountain]
and named the town Sung-kao (Revering the Heights)
[The Emperor] went eastward and ascended Mount Tai.
On the mountain the grass and leave of the trees had not yet sprouted,
so he ordered men to carry a stone stele up the mountain and erect it at the summit of Mount Tai.
Subsequently, the Sovereign went on a tour of inspection to the eastern seaboard
and conducted the rites of offering to the Pa-shen.
People from Ch'i who submitted memorials to the throne expounding on spirits, strange creatures, curiosities and [magical] methods numbered in the tents of thousands, .
but nothing could be verified.
Then more boats were sent out
with orders that the several thousands of individuals who had spoken about the sacred mountains in the middle of the sea should seek out the spirit beings of P'eng-lai.
Kung-sun Ch'ing usually went ahead carrying a caduceus to await events on each famous mountain.
When he reached [Mount] Tung-lai,
he said that during the night he saw a man,
several chang in height
who disappeared at his approach;
He saw his footprints were extremely large,
like those of a wild beast.
Among the assembled ministers some said they had seen an old man leading a dog;
he said,
"I wish to see the Chü Kung (Colossal Master)," whereupon he suddenly disappeared.
Having seen his footprints, the Sovereign
did not yet believe in it,
but when some of his ministers mentioned the old man,
he became utterly convinced it was an immortal.
He lingered awhile on the seacoast,
placing post carriages at the disposal of the practitioners of [magical] methods, and secretly sent men in the thousands to search for immortals.
In the fourth month (30 April-29 May 110 B.C)
the Sovereign reached Feng-kao on his return journey.

He reflected on [the fact that] the words of the assembled Confucian scholars and practitioners of [magical] methods in discussing the Feng and the Shan [sacrifices] differed from one man to the other,
were inconsistent,
and difficult to put into effect.
The Son of Heaven arrived in Liang-fu
where in accordance with the rites he sacrificed to the Ti Chu (Lord of the Earth).
On the yi-mao day (17 May 110 B.C.),
he ordered those Confucians among the Palace Attendants to don their caps and padded sashes,
shoot the sacrificial ox, and perform the sacrifice.
The Feng Sacrifice was conducted at the foot of Mount T'ai to the east,
the ritual being like that for the Chiao Sacrifice to the Grand Unity.
The sacificial mound was one chang and two ch'ih on a side
and nine ch'ih high.
Below it there were documents written on jade tablets
whose contents were kept secret.
After the seremony was completed,
the Son of Heaven, accompanied solely by the Palace Attendant and [Chief Commandant] of Imperial Equipages, [Huo] Tzu-hou, ascended Mount T'ai
where the Feng Sacrifice was performed anew,
this time in strictest secrecy.
The next day,
the Emperor descended via the path on the north slope.
On the ping-chen day (May 110 B.C.),
he performed the Shan Sacrifice on Mount Su-jan (Solemn Appearing) below Mount T'ai on the northeast,
the ritual used resembling thee sacrifice to the Mother Earth.
For each [ceremony] the Son of Heaven dressed in vestments that exalted yellow and in all he prostrated himself, (look below)
and music was exhaustively employed.(look above)
Rushes with three-lobed stalks from between the Chiang and Huai [rivers] were used to make the sacred mats,
and more earth in each of the five colors was matched and added to the altar mound.
Rare animals, flying birds, and white pheasants and various other animals from distant quarters of the world
were all released and used to augment the sacrificial offerings.
Animals like rhinoceroses and elephants were not offered up.
They arrived at Mount T'ai and afterward they left.
During the Feng and Shan sacrifices
the night seemed to be lit up by a gleam of light,
and during daylight white clouds rose from the middle of the altar mound.
On returning from the Feng and Shan sacrifices,
the Son of Heaven seated himself in the Ming T'ang,
and the assembled ministers in turn offered their salutations.
At this, the Emperor issued an edict to the [Grand master of the] Imperial Scribes:
"With an insignificant body, We have inherited the most exalted status;
[We] tremble with fear at it lest [We] not be up to the task.
For [Our] virtue is scant and meager,
and [We] have no understanding of the rites and music.
"When [We] performed the sacrifice to the Grand Unity,
it seemed there was a phenomenon of an auspicious gleam of light,
which suddenly could be seen.
[We] were deeply shaken by these unnatural happenings
and wished to stop, but [We] dared not,
finally ascending Mount T'ai and offering the Feng Sacrifice,
then [We] went to Liang-fu,
and afterward performed the Shan Sacrifice at Mount Su-jan.
"Having renewed [ourself] thereby,
[We] felicitate all officers and grandees by granting them a new beginning.
To every one hundred households among the people let there be given one ox and ten shih of wine,
to the elderly eighty years and over, orphans, and widows, add two bolts of hemp and silk cloth.
Po, Feng-kao, Yi-ch'iu, and Li-ch'eng,
shall be exempted from this year's land tax and] capitation] taxes.
"Let there be a general amnesty throughout the world,
like the amnesty order in the year yi-mao (120 B.C.).
Where this tour [of inspection] has passed, none shall be sentenced to light penal servitude
and those crimes that occurred prior to two years ago
shall be exempted from prosecution."
The Emperor further issued an edict that said:
"In ancient times, when the Son of Heaven conducted a tour of inspection every five years
and held [sacrificial] events on mount T'ai,
the feudal lords all had place to lodge when they came to pay him homage.
Let the feudal lords be ordered each to construct lodgings at the foot of Mount T'ai!"
After having completed the Feng and Shan sacrifices on Mount T'ai
without a calamity involving wind or rain,
the practioners of [magical] methods one after another spoke about P'eng-lai and the sacred mountains, as if they were now nearly within reach.
At this, the Sovereign was pleased at the prospect of encountering them
and again went east to the seacoast to gaze into the distance,
in hopes of encountering P'eng-lai there.
His [Chief Commandant] of Imperial Equipages, [Huo] Tzu-hou, became violently ill
and died within a day.
The The Emperor then departed,
heading northward along the coast
until he reached [Mount] Chieh-shih,
where he made an inspection tour starting at Liao-hsi Commandery
that traversed the northern borderlands and reached Chiu-yüan.
In the fifth moth,
the Emperor reached Kan-ch'üan on the return journey.
The authorities concerned proposed that, since the appearance of the precious tripod was commemorated by inaugurating the Yüan-ting (Tripod Origination) reign period,
the present year should be the inaugural year of the Yüan-feng (Feng Sacrifice Origination) reign period.
That autumn (110 B.C.),
there was a pei star in [the constellation] Tung ching (Eastern Well).
Just over ten days later,
there was a pei star in [the constellation] San T'ai.
The Observer of Emanations, Wang Shuo, said:
While I was watching, only I saw the star appear like a gourd,
and in time it takes to eat a meal it was gone again.
The authorities concerned said:
"Your Majesty inaugurated the Feng and Shan sacrifices for the House of Han;
Heaven is no doubt responding with a Te hsing (Star of Virtue)!"
In the winter of the nest year [109 B.C.],
the Emperor conducted the Chiao Sacrifice to the Five Emperors at Yung.
On his return,
he performed prostrations, prayers, and sacrifices to the Grand Unity.
The liturgy of praise accompanying the sacrifice said:
"The Star of Virtue, espansive in its brillance,
is auspicious.
The Shou hsing (Star of Longevity) appeared with it,
its gleam shining far and wide.
The Hsin hsing (Saturn) appeared brightly,
and the August Emperor respectfully prostrated himself in response to the Grand Supplicator's sacrifices."
That spring,
Kung-sun Ch'ing said he had seen a spirit man on Mount Tung-lai who is supposed to have said,
"[I want to] see the Son of Heaven."
At this the Son of Heaven favored Kou-shih City with a visit
and appointed [Kung-sun] Ch'ing as Regular Grand Master.
He then went to [Mount] Tung-lai
and, having so journed for several days,
did not see anything
except the footprints of a great man.
The Emperor again dispatched practitioners of [magical] methods in the thousands to seek out spirits and anomalies and collect medicinal fungi.
There was a draughts this year.
Therefore, there being no formal reason stated for his having gone out, the Son of Heaven
prayed [for rain] at Wan-li-sha
and, on passing Mount T'ai, offered sacrifices there.
On his return he reached Hu-tzu,
where he personally, where he personally oversaw the blocking of the breaches in the Ho dikes.
He stayed for two days,
sank offerings [in the Ho], and left.
He dispatched two excellencies to command the troops blocking breaches in the Ho dikes
and lead the flood waters off into two channels,
so as to restore the Ho at that place to its former course from the time of Yü.
At this time, after having annihilated Nan Yüeh,
a man of Yüeh, Yung Chih, said: "It is custumary among the people of Yüeh to believe in ghosts
and at their sacrifices they always saw ghosts;
of this there are numerous proofs.
Formerly, the king of Tung-ou was reverential toward the ghosts,
and lived to be 160 years old.
But subsequent generations became neglectent and indifferent,
and so they declined and died."
Thus the Emperor ordered a shamaness from Yüeh to establish prayers and sacrifices in the Yüeh [style],
installing a platform without altar;
she also sacrificed to the Spirit of Heaven, the Supreme Deity, and the hundred ghosts.
divining by means of chickens.
Because the Sovereign placed hos faith in these [methods of divination],
the Yüeh sacrifices and chicken divination thenceforth began to be employed.
Kung-sun Ch'ing said,
"The immortals can be seen;
Your Majesty always goes forth in such haste,
and for this reason doesn't see them.
Now, if Your Majesty can build a tower
like that of Kou-shih City wall,
and there set out dried meat and jujubes,
immortals could probably be induced to come.
Moreover, the immortals are fond of dwelling in towers."
At this, the Sovereign ordered the Fei Lien and the Kuei Kuan (The Cassia Towers) to be built at Ch'ang-an,
and the Yi and Yen-shou Kuan (Towers of Increase and the Prolonged Longevity) to be built at Kan-ch'üan,
and dispatched [Kung-sun] Ch'ing with an [imperial
Then [the Emperor] built the Tung-t'ien T'ai (Terrace for Cmmunication with Heaven),
and installed the sacrificial implements at its base,
in anticipation of summoning the spirits, immortals and their like.
At this, the palace at Kan-ch'üan was expanded by adding a Front Hall,
and all the palace rooms were enlarged for the first time.
In the summer,
a [Spirit] Fungus grew inside a room at the hall.
The Son of Heaven having blocked the Ho [dikes]
and raised the Terrace for Communication with Heaven,
brillant light was said to have appeared,
and the Emperor issued an edict saying.
"As a nine-stemmed [Spirit] Fungus has grown in a room in Kan-chüan Palace,
let there be a general amnesty
and no light penal servitude."
The following year [108 B.C.],
there was a punitive attack on Ch'ao-hsien (Korea);
in summer,
there was a drought.
Kung-sun Ch'ing said:
"In the Huang-ti's time, when the Feng Sacrifice was performed there was a drought
that dried the earthen altar mound [feng] for three years."
The Sovereign then issued an edict saying:
"Does Heaven intend with this drought
to dry the earthen altar mound?
The following year [107 B.C.],
the Sovereign performed the Chiao Sacrifice at Yung,
opened the Hui-chung Road,
and made a tour of inspection on it.
In the spring,
he reached Ming-tse
then returned via Hsi-ho [Commandery].
In the winter of the next year [106 B.C.],
the Sovereign conducted a tour of inspection of Nan Commandery;
reaching Chiang-ling, he returned eastward.
He ascended Mount Tien-chu (Heaven's Pillar) in Ch'ien [County] and performed rites there,
designating it Nan Commandery;
reaching Chiang-ling,
he turned eastward.
he ascended Mount T'ien-chu (Heaven's Pillar) in Ch'ien [County]

and performed rites there, designating it Nan Yüeh (Southern Sacred Peak). He embarked at Hsün-yang and boated down the Chiang [Yangtze River] as far as Tsung-yang, [along the way] passing by P'eng-li where he sacrificed to the famous streams and mountains of the region.
Turning north he reached Lang-ya,
he travelled via the seacoast.
In the middle of the fourth month,
he reached Feng-kao where he performed the Feng Sacrifice.
Earlier,
the Son of Heaven performed the Feng Sacrifice at Mount T'ai;
