Does the emperor think he can wipe out all of Xiang Yu's former followers?
The emperor has only just won control of the world.
Now when he is to search all over for one man simply because of some private resentment he bears,
what an example of pettiness he will be showing to the world!
"Furthermore, if Ju Bu is a worthy man as you say,
and if the emperor continues to search for him with such diligence,
he is sure to flee either to the barbarians in the north
or the people of Yue in the south.
This driving fine men to the aid of enemy states because of resentment
is the sort of thing that led to Wu Zixu's
thrashing the corpse of King Ping of Chu.327
Why do you not at some propitious moment speak to the emperor on his behalf?"
Lord Teng was aware that Zhu Jia was renowned as a chivalrous gentleman
and he guessed that Ji Bu was hiding at this home.
So he consented to Zhu Jia's request and,
when he found the emperor at leisure,
spoke to him as Zhu Jia had suggested.
The emperor accordingly pardoned Ji Bu.
Gentlemen of the day
all admired Ji Bu for being able
to swallow his pride and assume a subservient role,
while Zhu Jia also became famous in his time because of the incident.
Ji Bu was summoned to appear before the emperor,
and begged forgiveness for his (p.249) offence.
The emperor honoured him with the post of palace attendant.
During the reign of Emperor Hui
he was made general of palace attendants.
The Shanyu once sent an insulting and immodest letter to Empress LY.328
Empress LY was furious
and summoned all the generals to discuss what should be done.
Fan Kuai, the supreme general, said,
"I beg to be given a force of 100,000 men,
and I shall trample the Xiongnu underfoot!"
All the other generals, toadying to the empress's will,
seconded the request,
but Ji Bu announced,
"Fan Kuai deserves to be beheaded!
Emperor Gaozu in command of a force of over 300,000329
met serious difficulty from the Xiongnu at Pingcheng.
How does Fan Kuai think he is going to take 100,000 men
and 'trample the Xiongnu underfoot'?
He is lying to Her Majesty's face!
Furthermore, it was because the Qin government was so occupied with barbarian affairs
that Chen She and the rest were able to start a rebellion.
The wounds of that strife have still not healed,
yet Fan Kuai speaks flattery to Her Majesty's face
and would bring new unrest to the empire!"
At these words the entire throne room was filled with fear.
Empress Lyu dismissed the court
and did not again bring up the question of a compaign against the Xiongnu.
Ji Bu became governor of Hedong Province.
In the time of Emperor Wen
someone praised him as a worthy man,
whereupon Emperor Wen summoned him to the capital,
expecting to make him grand secretary.
Someone else, however reported that Ji Bu was reckless,
difficult when in his cups, and hard to get to know.
When Ji Bu arrived
the emperor kept him at the governor's lodge for a month
and then dismissed him and sent him back to Hedong.
On the occasion of his departure Ji Bu appeared before the emperor and said,
"Although I was without distinction, I received undeserved favour,
and humbly and diligently went to persue my duties in Hedong.
Then for no apparent reason Your Majesty summoned me to the capital.
It must have been that someone gave an exaggerated report of my worth.
Yet, that I have arrived,
I am assigned no new task,
but instead am dismissed and sent back again.
I suppose this is because this time some person has spoken ill of me.
In other words, because of one man's recommendation
Your Majesty summoned me,
and because of one man's slander
I am now being dismissed.
I fear if such an affair should come to the ears of knowledgeable men of the world,
they might draw conclusions concerning Your Majesty's judgement."
The emperor sat for a long while in embarrassed silence
and at last said,
"Hedong is a province of vital importance to me.
Therefore I wished to make a special point of summoning you for the position, that is all."
Ji Bu took his leave and went back to his post.
There was a rhetorician named Master Cao Qiu, a native of Chu,
who from time to time made up to influencial people with an eye to receiving money.
He performed services for the eunuch Zhao Tan and other famous people,
and was a friend of Dou Changjun, Emperor Jing's uncle.
Ji Bu, hearing of this,
sent a letter reprimanding Dou Changjun.
"From what I have heard, Cao Qiu is not a good man", he wrote.
"I would not have anything to do with him if I were you!"
I happened that Cao Qiu was making a visit to his native place
and he asked Dou Changjun to give him a letter of introduction to Ji Bu.
"General Ji does not care for you," replied Dou Changjun.
"I advise you not to go to see him."
But Cao Qiu pressed his request until he got the letter and,
when he started on his way,
he sent a man ahead to deliver it.
As might be expected, Ji Bu awaited Cao Qiu's visit with great anger.
When Cao Qiu appeared
he gave only a slight bow and said to Ji Bu,
"People of Chu have a saying that
100 catties of pure gold
are not as good as one of Ji Bu's promises.
I wonder how you managed to get such a reputation
in this region of Liang and Chu?
Now I am a man of Chu
and you are a man of Chu as well.
In the course of my travels I could spread your fame all over the world.
Would that not be even better than being famous in Liang and Chu?
Why do you object to me so?"
With this Ji Bu took a great liking to Cao Qiu
and instisted upon
keeping him at his home for several months,
treating him as an honoured guest
and giving him a generous farewell party.
As a result of Cao Qiu's efforts to spread his fame,
Ji Bu's renown grew even greater than before.
Ji Bu's younger brother Ji Xin
wielded great influence in the area within the Pass.
He treated others respectfully
and was fond of performing chivalrous actions,
so that for a thousand miles around
men vied with one another for honour to serve him to the death.
He once murdered a man
and fled to Wu,
getting Yuan Ang to hide him.
He looked up to Yuan Ang as a superior
and treated Guan Fu, Ji Fu, and others like younger brothers.
He once acted as marshal for the
military commander, Zhi Du,
who did not dare to treat him (p.251) disrespectfully.
Many of the young men of the time, when they
carried out some deed or other, would often claim that they were secretely acting in Ji Xin's name.
Ji Xin and Bu were both renowned throughout the area within the Pass,
the former for his bravery
In their day
Ji Bu's mother's younger brother, Lord Ding,
was a general of Chu.
While serving under Xiang Yu
he once persued Gaozu and his men west of Pengcheng.
Lord Ding's forces bore down upon them and the men had closed swords
when Emperor Gaozu, sorely pressed,
turned about and said to Lord Ding,
"Why should two worthy men like us vex one another in this way?"
With this, Lord Ding called off his troops and withdrew,
allowing Gaozu to escape unharmed.
After Xiang Yu had been destroyed
Lord Ding came to visit Gaozu.
Gaozu had him seized and paraded before his army,
announcing,
"Lord Ding was disloyal in his service to Xiang Yu.
It was none other than he
who caused Xiang Yu to lose the empire!"
Then he ordered Lord Ding beheaded.
"I want to make sure," he said,
"that no subject hereafter shall imitate Lord Ding's example!"
Luan Bu
was a native of Liang.
When Peng Yue, the king of Liang, was still a commoner
he and Luan Bu were friends.
Finding themselves impoverished,
they travelled together to Qi to seek employment as wage labourers,
becoming bond servants to a wine maker.
After several years
Peng Yue went off to the marsh of Juye and became a bandit,
but Luan Bu was seized and sold
as a slave in Yan.
There he carried out a vendetta for his master,
and the Yan general Zang Tu, hearing of this,
raised him to the position of colonel.
Later, after Zang Tu became king of Yan,
he made Luan Bu a general.
When Zang Tu revolted,
the Han forces attacked Yan
and took Luan Bu prisoner.
Peng Yue, the king of Liang, hearing of this,
sent word to the emperor
asking that he be allowed to ransom Luan Bu and make him a courtier of Liang.
The request was granted and Luan Bu was sent on a mission to Qi but,
before he had returned,
Gaozu summoned Peng Yue to the capital,
accused him of plotting revolt,
and executed him along with the members of his family to the third degree.
This done, he had the head of Peng Yue exposed in the city of Luoyang
with an edict posted below it reading,
"Whoever shall dare to dispose of or look after this head
shall be immediately arrested."
When Luan Bu passed by on his way back from Qi,
he reported on his mission before the head of Peng Yue,
sacrificed to it, and lamented.
The officials (p.252) arrested Luan Bu and submitted an account of what had happened.
The emperor had Luan Bu brought before him
cursed him, saying,
"Were you plotting rebellion along with Peng Yue?
I forbade any man to tend to his head,
yet you ventured to sacrifice and weep to it.
It is clear that you are as disloyal as Peng Yue.
Boil this man alive at once!"
After the necessary preparations, Luan Bu was dragged forward
and was about to be thrown into the boiling water
when he turned to the emperor and said,
"I beg to speak one word before I die."
"What is it you would say?" asked the emperor.
"When Your Majesty was in trouble in Pengcheng
and suffered defeat in the area of Xingyang and Chenggao
[3 lines below]
it was only because Peng Yue occupied the region of Liang
and co-operated with the Han forces in harassing the Chu armies
that Xiang Yu was in the end unable to advance further west.
At that time
all depended upon a nod from Peng Yue.
If he joined with Chu, then Han would be lost;
if he joined with Han, then Chu would be defeated.
Again, when the armies came together at Gaixia,
if Peng Yue had not appeared,
Xiang Yue would never have been destroyed.
"After the world was at peace
Peng Yue received the split tallies and the rites of enfeoffment as a king,
and his hope was that he might hand them down to his heirs for ten thousand generations.
Yet recently Your Majesty sent out a single call for troops from Liang and,
because King Peng was ill and did not respond,
you suspected him of disaffection.
And then, before evidence of revolt had even been found,
he was suspected to a cruel inquisition and he and his family wiped out.
Such treatment must surely fill every other worthy minister
with terror and doubt.
Now that King Peng is dead
I too will be better off dead than alive.
I beg you to proceed with the boiling!"
Hearing these words, the emperor pardoned his offence, set him free
and made him a colonel.
During the reign of Emperor Wen,
Luan Bu became prime minister of Yan
and later a general.
He used to say,
"If, when things are going poorly,
a man cannot endure some shame and modify his ambitions,
he is no man;
And if, when he had become rich and honoured,
he cannot fulfill his heart's desires,
he is no sage!"
Accordingly he repaid with great generosity all those who in the past had done him favours and,
in the case of those he bore grudges against, he used the law to wipe them out.
When the army of Chu revolted
he won military merit and was enfeoffed as marquis of Yu,
and once more became prime minister of Yan.
Throughout Yan and Qi altars were set up to him,
called "Altars of Lord Luan".
He died in the fifth year of the middle era of the reign of Emperor Jing (145 BC).
His son Luan Fen succeeded to the marquisate
and was made master of ritual,
but he was condemned for performing sacrifices in a manner at variance with the law
and his territory was taken away.
The Grand Historian remarks:
With a spirit like that of Xiang Yu,
Ji Bu made name for daring in Chu.
Form time to time he commanded armies
and several times seized the enemy pennants.
He deserves to be called a brave man.
Yet he suffered punishment and disgrace
and became a slave and did not commit suicide.
Why did he stoop to this?
Because he chose to rely upon his abilities.
Therefore he suffered disgrace withour shame,
for there were things he hoped to accomplish and he was not yet satisfied.
Thus in the end he became a renowned general of Han.
Truly the wise man regards death as a grave thing.
When slaves and scullion maids and such mean people in their dispair
commit suicide
it is not because they are brave;
it is because they know that their plans and hopes will never again have a chance of becoming true!
Luan Bu wept for Peng Yue
and hastened to the boiling water as though it was his true destination.
This is indeed what it means to know the right place to die,
not counting death as important in itself.
The most determined men of ancient times
could do no better than these two!
Yuan Ang,
whose polite name was Yuan Si, was a native of Chu.
His father had at one time been a member of a robber band,
but later moved to Anling.330
During the reign of Empress Ly,
Yuan Ang became a retainer of Ly Lu,
and after Emperor Wen came to the throne,
on the recommendation of his elder brother Yuan Kuai,
he was made a palace attendant.
At this time Zhou Bo, the marquis of Jiang, was acting as chancellor.
As soon as court was over Zhou Bo used to hurry out of the palace
with an air of great importance
and the emperor, who treated him with extreme deference,
would always sit watching him until he had left the room.331
One day Yuan Ang stepped forward from his place and asked,
"In Your Majesty's opinion, what sort of man is the chancellor?"
"He is a veritable guardian of the altars of the nation," replied the emperor.
"Zhou Bo may indeed be termed a worthy minister," said Yuan Ang,
"but he is no guardian of the nation.
A true guardian of the nation will serve his lord while his lord lives,
but if his lord should perish he will perish with him.
In the time of Empress Ly
the members of the Ly family wielded power in the government
and arbitrarily made themselves kings and ministers,
so that the life of the Liu dynasty hung by a thread.
At that time Zhou Bo was grand commandant
and was in charge of the military,
and yet he was not able to remedy the situation.
After Empress Ly passed away,
when the high officials plotted to overthrow the Ly clan,
Zhou Bo, because of his office as grand commandant,
happened to win a measure of success.
Therefore I say he may be termed a worthy minister,
but hardly a guardian of the altars of the nation.
He appears before the ruler with an arrogant air,
while Your Majesty is polite and yielding,
so that the proper etiquette between ruler and subject is turned upside down.
For Your Majesty's sake may I make bold to suggest that such a situation is unacceptable."
After this the emperor behaved with greater austerty in court,
and Zhou Bo approached him with increasing awe.
Form this time on Zhou Bo came to hate Yuan Ang.
"Your brother and I are good friends,
and yet now you are trying to destroy my reputation at court!" he complained,
but Yuan Ang refused to offer any apology.
Afte Zhou Bo retired from the position of chancellor
and returned to his territory in Jiang
one of the natives of the place sent a report to the throne
that Zhou Bo was planning to revolt.
Zhou Bo was summoned and brought in chains to the inquiry room,
but none of the court officials or members of the imperial family
dared to speak a word in his defence.
Only Yuan Ang pleaded for him and proved that he was not guilty.
His eventual release
was due entirely to the efforts of Yuan Ang,
and after this the two became close friends.
When Liu Chang, the king of Huainan and younger brother of Emperor Wen, came to the capital to pay his respects,
he killed Shen Yiji, the marquis of Biyang,
and conducted himself with the utmost arrogance.
Yuan Ang warned the emperor,
"If the feudal lords are allowed to become too arrogant,
they will surely breed mischief.
It would be well to punish him by depriving him of part of his territory."
But Emperor Wen refused to listen to this advice,
and the king of Huainan became increasingly high-handed.
Later it was discovered that the heir of Chai Wǔ32, the marquis of Jipu,
was plotting revolt;
he was brought to trial,
and investigation revealed that the king of Huainan was implicated in the plot.
The emperor summoned the king from his territory and ordered him exiled to Shu,
imprisoning him in a caged cart and sending him by post relay.
(p.455) Yuan Ang, who at this time was general of the palace attendants,
admonished the emperor, saying,
"Your Majesty originally encouraged the king of Huainan in his arrogant ways
and made no attempt to curb him,
until affairs reached this pass.
Now with sudden severity you have struck him down.
The king of Huainan is a man of implacable spirit.
If, exposed to the cold and damp of the road, he should die along the way,
it would appear that Your Majesty,
with the vast expanse of the empire at your command,
could not bear to grant him a single place to rest!
What if you should incur the name of a fraticide?"
But the emperor refused to listen
and sent the king of Huainan on his way.
When the king reached Yong
he fell ill and died.
Informed of his death,
the emperor refused to eat
and gave himself up to the bitterest lamentations.
Yuan Ang came before him and,
bowing his head, begged pardon for not having urged his counsel more strongly.
said the emperor.
"All this happened because I did not listen to your words,"
said Yuan Ang.
"Your Majesty must take heart,"
The thing has already happened.
What good is there in regrets?
Moreover, Your Majesty has on three occasions displayed conduct for above the standard of the age.
This present affair is not important enough
to efface the fair name you have earned in the past."
"And what are these three examples of outstanding conduct?"
asked the emperor.
When Your Majesty was still king of Dai
your mother, the queen dowager, was ill
for three years.
During that time you did not shut your eyes in sleep,
you did not doff your robes;
No broth of herbs was presented to her until you in person had tasted it.
Even Zeng Can, the paragon of filial piety in ancient times,
though only a commoner, could hardly have done as much.
Yet you, a king, behaved in such a way,
far surpassing the filial piety of Zeng Can.
Again, when the Ly family dominated the throne
and the high ministers wielded power at their pleasure,
Your Majesty journeyed to the capital from Dai in a party of only six relay carriages,
hastening into what lair of dangers you knew not.
Even the heroes of antiquity Meng Ben and Xia Yu could not match such bravery.
Finally, when you reached the state residence of Dai
you faced west and declined twice to accept the throne and,
facing south, declined it three times again.
Xu You in ancient times declined such an offer once, we are told,
but Your Majesty surpassed him by four times.
When you exiled the king of Huainan to Shu
it was your intention merely (p.456) to humble his spirit
and lead him to reform his ways.
It was only because of the laxity of the officials who were guarding him
that he fell ill and died."
His grief somewhat assuaged,
the emperor asked,
"What should I do now?"
"The king of Huainan left three sons," replied Yuan Ang.
"Their fate is in Your Majesty's hands."
Emperor Wen proceeded to make kings of the three sons of Liu Chang.
Because of this incident,
Yuan Ang's name commanded even greater respect at court.
Yuan Ang was a man of fierce loyalty and was motivated in all his conduct by the highest principles.
because of his knowledge of numerology had gained favaour with Emperor Wen.
This man took every opportunity to speak ill of Yuan Ang,
until Yuan Ang began to fear that some misfortune would befall him.
Yuan Zhong, the son of Yuan Ang's elder brother,
was a horseman in the emperor's retinue
and used to bear the imperial credentials and accompany the emperor's carriage.
He advised his uncle, saying,
"You had best have an open conflict with Zhao Tan
and shame him before the court,
so that the emperor will pay no more attention to his slander."333
Accordingly, when Emperor Wen left the palace one day
in his carriage accompanied by Zhao Tan,
Yuan Ang prostrated himself before the carriage and said,
" I have always been told that only the most distinguished men of the empire
are privileged to ride with the Son of Heaven in his six-foot carriage of state.
Now although the Han may be lacking in worthy men,
I cannot imagine why Your Majesty would deign to ride in the same carriage
with a man who is more than a remnant of the knife and saw!"334
The emperor laughed
and ordered Zhao Tan to get down from the carriage.
Weeping bitterly, Zhao Tan descended.
Another time Emperor Wen had ridden in his carriage to the top of the hill at Baling
and was proposing to gallop down the steep slope to the west.
Yuan Ang, accompanying the emperor on horseback,
stood by the emperor's carriage, pulling at the reins of the emperor's horses.
"What is the matter, General Yuan?" asked the emperor. "Are you afraid?"
"I have heard people say," replied Yuan Ang,
"that the heir to an estate of 1,000 pieces of gold
should not sit on the edge of a porch for fear he might fall (p.457) off;
that the heir of an estate of 100 gold pieces
should not lean on the railings for fear they might break;
and that the sacred ruler of the nation should not courty danger in his carriage
and trust all to mere luck!
Now Your Majesty proposes to gallop down a steep slope
in a carriage draws by six horses.
If the horses should become frightened and the carriage upset,
you may think what might happen to you of little importance,
but what of your duty to the ancestral temple of your father and to your mother?"
The emperor gave up the idea.
Emperor Wen was one time paying a visit to the Shanglin Park,
accompanied by the empress and his favourite concubine, Lady Shen.
In the inner rooms of the palace it was customary
for the empress and Lady Shen to sit side by side on the same mat as though they were equals
and, when the party came to take their seats in the park,
the official in charge of the arrangements spread the mats in the usual fashion.
But Yuan Ang pulled Lady Shen's mat back a little way from that of the empress.
Lady Shen was furious
and refused to take her seat,
and the emperor, also in rage,
got up
and went back to the palace.
When the opportunity presented itself Yuan Ang appeared before the emperor and said,
"I have heard it say that only when the proper hierarchical distinctions are observed
is there harmony between superiors and inferiors.
Now Your Majesty has already chosen an empress,
while Lady Shen is no more than a concubine.
How is it possible that a concubine and her mistress should sit side by side?
Your Majesty is pleased with Lady Shen
and naturally you wish to shower her with favours.
But though you may believe that you are doing it for her sake,
you may in fact be bringing disaster upon her.
Has Your Majesty alone not seen the 凐uman pig'?"335
The emperor was pleased with his words and,
summoning Lady Shen, explained the situation to her.
She in turn rewarded Yuan Ang with a gift of fifty catties of gold.
Yuan Ang continued to admonish the emperor form time to time
in this outspoken fashion, however,
so that he was not permitted to stay for long at court,
but was transferred to the position of colonel of Longxi province.
He treated the soldiers under his command with great compassion,
and there was not one who would have hesitated to die for him.
He was transferred to the position of prime minister of Qi,
and later to that of prime minister of Wu.
When he was taking leave to go to his last appointment
his nephew Yuan Zhong said (p.458) to him,
"Liu Pi, the king of Wu, has for a long time grown more overbearing each day,
and his kingdom is guilty of numerous irregularities.
But if now you should attempt to expose him and bring order,
he would either send some slanderous report to the emperor about you,
or dispatch you at once with the point of a sword!
The kingdom of Wu lies in the south, a damp and swampy region.
You must take care to eat and drink your daily fill,
and not worry yourself about other things.
From time to time you may urge the king not to revolt, and that is all.
If you do this, you may be fortunate enough to escape harm!"
Yuan Ang did as his nephew suggested,
and was treated with favour by the king of Wu.
After some time he was granted permission to return to the capital for a visit.
In the street he happened to meet the chancellor, Shentu Jia.
Yuan Ang descended form his carriage and went over to greet the chancellor,
but Shentu Jia merely acknowleged the greeting without getting down from his own carriage.
Yuan Ang returned to his company,
filled with embarrassment at the insult he had suffered before the eyes of his own officials.
He went at once to the office of the chancellor, where he sent in his name card
and requested an interview with Shentu Jia.
After keeping him waiting for a long time the chancellor granted him an interview.
Yuan Ang knelt before the chancellor and said,
"I would like to speak with you in private."
"If what you have to say concerns some public matter,
you may go to the proper office and discuss it with my secretary or one of the clerks,
and in due time I will present your report to the throne.
But if you have come on private business,
you should know that I do not discuss matters of a private nature!"
Still kneeling before him, Yuan Ang said,
"Now that you have become chancellor,
do you consider yourself
the equal of your predecessors in office, Chen Ping and Zhou Bo?"
"Surely not,"
replied Shentu Jia.
"Fine.
So you admit you are not their equal.
Chen Pi and Zhou Bo were both outstanding statesmen and generals.[3 lines below]
They assisted Emperor Gaozu
in the conquest of the empire,
[3 lines above]
and later overthrew the Ly clan
and rescued the emperial family from peril.
You began your career, I believe, as a corssbow man,
and were transferred to the position of head of a battalion.
Later, bacause of your services, you managed to become governor of Huaiyang,
but I do not recall that you won any distinction for far-sighted strategies
or exploits on the fields of battle.
"Since the present emperor arrived from Dai to take the throne,
he has always listened to the reports of the various palace attendants and officials
whenever he appeared in court.
I have never known him to refuse to stop his carriage
to listen to a word form one of them.
If the suggestion is of no worth, he merely sets it aside;
but if it proves to be sound, he always puts it into effect,
and never fails to commend the person who gave it.
Why is this?
Because he hopes thereby to attract to the court
the wisest and most worthy men of the empire.
Each day that he hears something he had not heard before,
or learns something that until then he was ignorant of,
he increases his august wisdom.
And yet now you would put a gag into the mouths of the empire,
so that each day you grow more ignorant.
If so wise a ruler were to reprimand so ignorant a minister,
I fear disaster would not be long in coming to you!"
Shentu Jia bowed to Yuan Ang several times,
"I am a stupid man," he said,
"I did not realize
that you would be kind enough to teach me my errors."
And he led Yuan Ang into his rooms
and placed him in the seat of honour.
Yuan Ang had always been on bad terms with Chao Cuo.
Whenever Chao Cuo came into a room and sat down
Yuan Ang would get up and leave,
and whenever Yuan Ang sat down
Chao Cuo would leave;
the two men would never sit talking in the same room together.
After Emperor Wen passed away
and Emperor Jing came to the throne
Chao Cuo was made imperial secretary.
He sent his officials to investigate charges that
Yuan Ang had accepted bribes from the king of Wu,
and had Yuan Ang convicted,
but the emperor issued an edict pardoning him
and demoting him to the rank of commoner.
When news came that the kings of Wu and Chu had revolted
Chao Cuo summoned his clerks and secretaries and told them,
"Yuan Ang accepted a number of gifts of money from the king of Wu
and exerted all his efforts to cover up the king's evil doings,
insisting that he had no thoughts of rebellion.
Now, as it turns out, he has revolted.
I want you to have Yuan Ang brought up for eximination.
He probably knows all about the plot to rebel."
But his clerks replied,
"Before the revolt broke out,
we might have been able to forestall it by examining Yuan Ang.
But now the rebel armies are already marching west toward the capital.
What profit would there be now in an investigation?
Anyway it is hardly likely that he had any part in the plot."
Chao Cuo hesitated and had not yet decided what course to take
when someone reported the affair to Yuan Ang.
Fearful of what might happen,
Yuan Ang went at night to see Dou Ying,
relating to him the causes of the revolt
and begging him to appear before the emperor
and explain the situation in person.
Dou Ying went to the emperor and spoke to him as Yuan Ang had asked,
whereupon the emperor sent for Yuan Ang to come to see him.
Chao Cuo was (p.460) with the emperor at the time but,
when Yuan Ang requested that the others be sent away
and he be granted a private interview,
Chao Cuo, much to his anger, was forced to withdraw from the room.
Yuan Ang then reported in full the reasons why the king of Wu had revolted,
laying the blame entirely on Chao Cuo.
"If only Chao Cuo were executed at once and apologies made to the king of Wu,
then he would surely halt his armies," he concluded.
(A fuller account will be found in the chapter on the king of Wu.)
The emperor appointed Yuan Ang as master of ritual
and made Dou Ying a general in chief.
The two men had long been friends,
and now that the kingdom of Wu was in revolt,
wealthy men from the various tomb towns around the capital,
as well as distinguished officials of Chang冠n, flocked to join the two,
so that the carriages in their train increased by several hundred each day.
After the emperor had executed Chao Cuo
he sent Yuan Ang to the state of Wu as master of ritual.
The king of Wu wanted to make Yuan Ang one of his generals but,
when Yuan Ang refused to consent,
he decided to kill him
and sent one of his colonels with a body of 500 men
to surround Yuan Ang and keep him under guard in the midst of the army camp.
Some years before, when Yuan Ang was acting as prime minister of Wu,
one of his subordinate officials was
carrying on a secret affair with a maidservant of Yuan Ang's.
Yuan Ang learned of the romance,
but mentioned it to no one
and continued to treat the official as before.
Someone warned the man that
his master knew all about the intrigue with the servant girl,
whereupon he attempted to run away.
But Yuan Ang galloped after him in person
and later presented him with the girl
and restored him to his official position.
Now when Yuan Ang was being held prisoner by the king of Wu,
it happened that the same official was acting
as marshal to the colonel who was in charge of guarding Yuan Ang.
The marshal proceeded to trade all his uniforms and possessions
for two large measures of rich wine, which he passed out among the soldiers guarding the southwest sector of the camp.
The weather was cold
and the sodiers were tired and hungry,
and it was not long before they all fell into a drunken sleep.
Then, under cover of darkness, the marshal roused Yuan Ang
and said,
"Now is your chance to escape!
The king of Wu has given orders to execute you tomorrow at dawn!"
"But who are you?" asked Yuan Ang incredulously.
"I am the official who used to serve under you
and was carrying on a secret affair with your maid," replied the marshal.
Yuan Ang was astonished but declined to take the opportunity to escape.
"Your parents, I trust, are still alive.
I could not bear to have you and your family involved in trouble on my account."
"Just go!" said the marshal.
"After you are gone I will run away too
and see to it that my parents escape into hiding.
What is there for you to worry about?"
Then he took a knive and, cutting a hole on the tent,
led Yuan Ang out past the drunken soldiers and directly out of the camp,
were the two of them parted.
Yuan Ang removed the oxtail pennant from his staff of office
and hid it in his breast and,
using the staff as a cane,
walked along the road for seven or eight li.
At dawn
he met some riders from the loyal armies of Liang,
who carried him off on their horses.
Eventually he returned to the capital and reported on his mission.
After the rebellion of Wu and Chu had been put down
the emperor set up Liu Li, the marquis of Pinglu and
the son of Liu Jiao, King Yuan of Chu, as king of Chu,
and appointed Yuan Ang to be his prime minister.
Yuan Ang sent reports to the throne containing various recommendations,
but his advice was never listened to and,
because of illness, he was relieved of his post.
After this he retired to his home in Anling,
where he mingled freely with the people of the neighbourhood
and joined them in cockfighting and dog racing.
Ju Meng of Luoyang336 once came to visit him,
and Yuan Ang received him with great courtesy.
A certain rich man of Anling remarked to Yuan Ang on this.
"I have heard that Ju Meng is a gambler.
I cannot imagine why a man like you, General Yuan, would have anything to do with him!"
"He may be a gambler," replied Yuan Ang,
"but when his mother died
the carriages of over 1,000 guests appeared to attend her funeral.
So he must be something more than an ordinary man.
Moreover, everybody finds himself sooner or later in serious trouble.
But if one morning you were to go with your troubles and knock on Ju Meng's gate,
he would not put you off with excuses about responsibility to his parents,
or try to avoid the issue because of the danger to himself.
The only men you can really court on in the world today
are Ji Xin337 and Ju Meng!
Now you go about with a retinue of several horsemen,
but if some day you find yourself in difficulty,
do you think they will be any help to you?"
So he railed at the rich man
and refused to have anything further to do with him.
(p.462) When people heard of the incident
they admired Yuan Ang more than ever.
Although Yuan Ang lived at home in retirement,
Emperor Jing form time to time sent men
to consult him on questions of government policy.
Liu Wu, the king of Liang and younger brother of Emperor Jing,
tried to have himself designated heir to the throne but,
after Yuan Ang advised against it,
all talk of such a move came to an end.
Because of this the king of Liang bore Yuan Ang a deep hatred
and even sent a man to assassinate him.
When the assassin reached the area within the Pass
and began to inquire about Yuan Ang,
he found that everyone he asked praised Yuan Ang
and could not say enough in his favour.
Finally he went to see Yuan Ang himself and said,
"I have received money from the king of Liang to come and kill you but,
because you are a worthy man,
I cannot bear to carry out my charge.
There will be ten or twelve others coming after me, though, to see that the deed is done!
You must be prepared!"
Yuan Ang grew very uneasy,
and in addition to this all sorts of strange things began to happen in the house,
until finally he went to the home of Master Pei, a diviner,
to inquire what the future held.
On his way home
the other assassins, who had come from Liang as the man had predicted,
surrounded him and stabbed him to death outside the city gate of Anling.
Chao Cuo
was a native of Yingchuan.
He studied the Legalist doctrines of Shen Buhai and Shang Yang
at the home of Master Zhang Hui in Zhi,
where he was a fellow student of Song Meng and Liu Li of Luoyang.
Because of his learning
he was made a custodian of ancient affairs under the master of ritual.
As a person Chao Cuo was always very severe and outspoken.
At this time, under the reign of Emperor Wen,
there was no one in the empire who knew much about the Book of Documents.
Only one man, a Master Fu of Ji南an,
who had formerly been an erudite under the Qin dynasty,
was said to have a thorough knowledge of the classic,
but Master Fu was already over ninety
and too old to summon to court.
The emperor therefore ordered the master of ritual
to send someone to receive instruction from the aged scholar.
The master of ritual dispatched Chao Cuo,
who went to the home of Master Fu and studied the Book of Documents with him.
After his return to court
Chao Cuo submitted a report to the throne recommending various improvements in the government,
in which he quoted from the Book of Documents and praised the teaching of his master.
The emperor appointed him as a retainer to the heir (p.463) apparent, and
in the course of time he rose to the position of gate keeper
and eventually that of steward.
He won great favour with the heir apparent because of his skill in discourse,
and was referred to by the members of the prince's household
as the "Wisdom Bag".
From time to time Chao Cuo submitted memorials to Emperor Wen
urging that the territories of the feudal lords be reduced in size
and the laws of the empire revised.
In all he sent in over ten reports.
Emperor Wen ignored the suggestions but,
inpressed by his ability,
transferred him to the position of palace counsellor.
The heir apparent was strongly in favour of his ideas,
but Yuan Ang and many of the other high officials disliked Chao Cuo.
When the heir apparent, Emperor Jing, ascended the throne,
he made Chao Cuo the prefect of the capital.
Chao Cuo often used to discuss matters of state with the emperor in private,
and the emperor readily listened to his advice.
Soon he enjoyed greater favour at the court than the highest officials,
and at his suggestion many changes were made in the laws of the empire.
The chancellor Shentu Jia was deeply resentful of Chao Cuo,
but did not have the means to strike back at him.
It happened that the office of the prefect of the capital was situated within
the outer wall of the mortuary temple of Gaozu's father, the Grand Supreme Emperor.
There was a gate to the east but,
because it was inconvinient to use,
Chao Cuo had a second gate constructed on the south side,
cutting a hole in the outer wall of the mortuary temple.
When Shentu Jia heard of this
he was furious
and decided to use the incident to trip up his enemy
and to submit a petition to the emperor for Chao Cuo's execution.
Chao Cuo got word of his plans and,
visiting the emperor in private at night,
explained his action in full.
Shentu Jia in due time submitted his petition,
accusing Chao Cuo of "piercing the wall of the mortuary temple
in order to make a gate",
and requesting that he be turned over to the commandant of justice for execution,
but the emperor replied,
"The wall in question is not the actual wall of the temple,
but an outer wall seperated from it by an open space.
There has been no infringement of the law."
Shentu Jia apologized for bringing up the matter and,
when court was over,
remarked angrily to his chief secretary,
"I should have executed him first and reported the matter afterward.
Instead I was mistaken enough to request permission,
and gave the little upstart a chance to trick me!"
Shortly afterwards Shentu Jia fell ill and died.
After this Chao Cuo commanded even greater honour,
and was transferred to the position of imperial secretary.
He began to submit reports to Emperor Jing (p.464) accusing the feudal lords of various crimes
and recommending that their territories be reduced
and the outlying provinces taked over by the central government.
The emperor brought his recommendation before the high officials
and the members of the aristocracy and imperial house for discussion,
but noneof them dared to express any opposition.
Only Dou Ying spoke out against them,
and because of this Chao Cuo and Dou Ying became enemies.
Chao Cuo succeeded in having thirty new statutes added to the laws,
though the feudal lords, who hated Chao Cuo, unanimously opposed all of them.
Chao Cuo's father, hearing of this,
journeyed from Yingchuan to the capital
and spoke to his son.
"Since the present emperor came to the throne,
who have wielded great power in the government,
but you have used it to trespass upon the feudal lords and deprive them of territory,
bringing dissension between the ruler and his own kin.
All men speak against you, and you have aroused bitter resentment in many quarters!
Why so you persist in such a course?"
"What you say is quite true," replied Chao Cuo.
"But if did not take these measures
the Son of Heaven would not receive the proper respect
and the ancestral temples of the Liu family would be imperiled!"
"The Liu family is safe enough," said the father.
"It is the Chao family that is in peril!
I will leave you now and go home."338
Shortly after this he swallowed poison and died,
declaring,
"I cannot bear to sit by until disaster comes to me as well!"
Some ten days after his death, as the old man had feared,
Wu, Chu, and the other states, seven in all, rose in revolt,
their objective, they declared, being to force the execution of Chao Cuo.
At the urge of Dou Ying and Yuan Ang,
the emperor ordered Chao Cuo to put on his court robes
and had him cut in two in the eastern market place of the capital.
After the death of Chao Cuo
there was a man named Lord Deng, the chief master of guests,
who was sent as a commander
to attack the armies of Wu and Chu. At the request of his superior general [punct.!]
he returned to the capital
to report to Emperor Jing on the progress of the campaign.
When he appeared in audience
the emperor said,
"You have just come from the battle area.
Now that the news of Chao Cuo's death has gone around,
have the armies of Wu and Chu begun to retreat?"
"The king of Wu has been plotting revolt for twenty or thirty years,"
replied Lord Deng.
"He was enraged over being deprived of territory
and used the execution of Chao Cuo as an excuse for taking action.
But it was not really Chao Cuo that he was concerned about.
Moreover, with what has happended now, I fear
that people in the empire will clamp their lips shut
and no one will ever dare to speak out again!"
"Why do you say that?" asked the emperor.
"Chao Cuo was afraid that the feudal lords would become so powerful
that they could no longer be held in check.
Therefore he requested that their territories be diminished in size
in order to increase the prestige of the central court.
He was thinking of what benefits such a policy would bring in long years to come.
But he had no sooner begun to put his plans into effect
than he suddenly found himself the victim of the direst penalty.
Your Majesty is gagging the mouths of your own ministers
in order to allay the hatreds of the feudal lords.
Such a policy, if I may say so, is hardly to Your Majesty's benefit."
Emperor Jing was silent,
and after a long time he said,
"You have spoken well,
I regret what I did."
He honoured Lord Deng with the post of military commander of Chengyang.
Lord Deng
was a native of Chenggu
and was noted for his wealth of unusual ideas and schemes.
During the era jianyuan (140-135 BC),
when Emperor Wu sent out a call for worthy men to take positions in the government,
the high officials all recommended Lord Deng.
Although Lord Deng had already retired from official life,
he left his home and re-entered government service, holding one of the most important posts.
After a year
he pleaded illness and once more returned to a life of retirement.
His son Deng Zhang was well known among the gentlemen of the time
as a devotee of the teachings of the Yellow Emperor and Lao Zi.
The Grand Historian remarks:
Although Yuan Ang had no fondness for learning,
he was clever at getting his point across.
At heart he was a kind man,
outspoken in his loyalty and devoted to the cause of duty.
He was fortunate enough to serve during the time of Emperor Wen,
when his talents were most suited to the age.
But the following reign saw changes that were, for him, less fortunate,
and though he made one recommendation at the time of the revolt of Wu and Chu,
and it was carried out,
it failed to have the desired effect of halting the rebellion.
He was too fond of fame and to boastful of his own worth,
so that in the end his reputation suffered.
Form the period when Chao Cuo was steward in the household of the heir apparent,
he began from time to time to submit recommendations to the throne,
though his suggestions were never followed.
After he became able to wield power at will in the government
he instituted a great many changes and innovations.
The feudal lords vehemently opposed him,
but instead of bending every effort to correct the situation and quit the discord,
he gave himself up to personal vindictiveness,
so in the end destruction fell upon himself.
The proverb has it that:
Meddle with custom, old ways emend,
and death or exile will be your end.
It refers, no doubt, to men like Chao Cuo.
The commandant of justice Zhang Shizhi,
whose polite name was Zhang Ji, was a native of Duyang.
He lived at home with his elder brother Zhang Zhong.
Because of the wealth of the family he was made a palace horseman339
and served under Emperor Wen.
In ten years of service, however, he failed to win any promotion
and remained completely unknown.
"I have been in government service for a long time
and used up all my brother's wealth,
but I have accomplished nothing,"
he said and requested that he be relieved of his post so that he could return home.
But the general of palace attendants Yuan Ang knew that he was a wothy man
and hated to see him leave,
so he arranged for him to be transferred to the post of master of guests.
After Zhang Shizhi had made his appearance in court and the usual ceremonies were over
he stepped forward and began to speak to the emperor on matters of government policy.
"I find your discourse somewhat too lofty," said Emperor Wen.
"Would you mind lowering the tone and
confining yourself to practical suggestions which can be put into effect at once?"
Zhang Shizhi accordingly began to speak of events of the Qin and Han,
explaining at great length why the Qin dynasty failed
and the Han was able to come to power.
The emperor was pleased with his words
and rewarded him with the position of chief master of guests.
Zhang Shizhi once accompanied Emperor Wen
on a visit to the Tiger Fold, the imperial zoo in the Shanglin Park.
The emperor questioned the keeper of the park about the list of birds and beasts that were housed in the zoo,
asking some ten or twelve questions,
but the keeper only looked about helplessly at this [sic!] assistants,
and no one was able to make any reply.
At this point one of the workman in the zoo who happened to be standing by
began to speak in place of the keeper, answering all the emperor's inquiries about the animals.
Making every effort to show off his ability,
he replied promptly and with complete ease to each question the emperor put to him.
"This is the way an official ought to be, is it not?
The keeper is unfit for his post!"
the emperor declared and ordered Zhang Shizhi to see to it
that the workman was appointed director of the Shanglin Park.
After some time Zhang Shizhi stepped forward and asked,
"What does Your Majesty think of the marquis of Jiang, Zhou Bo?"
"He is an excellent man," replied the emperor.
"And the marquis of Dongyang, Zhang Xiangru ?"
"He too is an excellent man."
"You have said that these two are excellent men,
and yet both of them, when questioned on some matter,
are frequently unable to give an immediate reply
Would You have them imitate this chattering workman with his glib tongue and ready answers?
The First Emperor of Qin entrusted his government to a lot of petty clerks,
who outdid each other in enforcing the letter of the law
and spying on people in order to enhance their own reputations.
Their fault was that they cared only for outward appearances
and had no real compassion for the people.
As a result the emperor was never informed of his faults,
and the situation continued to deteriorate until, in the time of the Second Emperor,
the dynasty collapsed and its empire fell to pieces
Now if Your Majesty were suddenly to select this workman for an official position because of his clever talk,
I am afraid that the world would be quick to see which way the wind is blowing
and people would begin outdoing each other in glib chatter
that has nothing to do with reality.
The governed respond to the influence of their governors
as swiftly as shadows or echoes.
One must therefore be very careful in this matter of selecting men for office!"
"Your are quite right," said the emperor,
and cancelled his order to make the workman an official.
When the emperor returned to his carriage
he invited Zhao Shizhi to ride with him and,
as they drove slowly back to the palace,
the emperor questioned him about the failings of the Qin dynasty.
He was impressed with the good sense of Zhang Shizhi's words and,
after they had returned to the palace,
promoted him to the position of master of the public carriage.
Sometime after Zhang Shizhi's appointment to this post
the heir apparent was visiting the court with his brother L?? Wu, the king of Liang.
When they drove through the marshal's gate, the main gate of the palace, they failed to alight from their carriage.
Zhang Shizhi, who was in charge of the gate, ran after them,
halted their carriage, and refused to allow them to enter
the inner gate to the reception hall.
He promptly submitted a report to the throne
accusing the two of lack of reference because they had failed to alight from their carriage at the main gate.
When word of the incident reached the emperor's mother, Empress Dowager Bo,
the emperor was obliged to visit his mother and, doffing his hat,
apologize for the incident.
"It is my fault," he said, "for failing to instruct my boys properly."
The empress dowager then sent a messenger to receive an order from the emperor
pardoning the heir apparent and his brother,
and after this they were permitted to enter the court.
Emperor Wen was much impressed by Zhang Shizhi's action
and promoted him to the position of palace counsellor.
After some time
Zhang Shizhi was advanced to the post of general of palace attendants.
Zhang Shizhi was at one time accompanying the emperor on a visit to the hill at Baling, which the emperor had selected as the site of his tomb.
The emperor was seated on the northers slope of the hill, gazing out over the countryside,
when he turned to his concubine, Lady Shen, who was attending him, and,
pointing to the Xinfeng road,
said,
"That is the road that goes to your native city of Handan!"
Then, asking Lady Shen to play on the zither,
he began to sing.
His voice was sad and full of longing.
Turning to his courtiers, he said,
"Ah!
if I could get some of the stones from those northers mountains to make my sarcophagus,
and then fill up the seams with silk waste
and seal it all with lacquer,
I would have a coffin that no thief could break into!"
"An excellent idea!" exclaimed the emperor's attendants,
but Zhang Shizhi came forward and, pointing to the south, said,
"If there are things in the tomb that men covet, then,
although you were to seal up the whole of those southern mountains with iron, the thieves would still find some crack to enter by.
But if you do not place such things inside the tomb,
then you may dispense even with the stone coffin
and there will be no danger of vandals."
Emperor Wen was (p.470) impressed by his words
and later promoted him to the position of commandant of justice.
One time
Emperor Wen had gone out on an excursion and
was passing over the middle of the three bridges that span the Wei River,
when a man suddenly ran out from under the bridge,
startling the horses of the emperors's party.
The emperor ordered his outriders to seize the man
and hand him over to Zhang Shizhi, the commandant of justice.
When Zhang Shizhi questioned him
then man replied,
"I come form the district around here and was on the way to the capital
when I heard the order to clear the road for the emperor,
so I hid under the bridge.
After a long while
I supposed that the emperor had already gone over
and I came out.
Then I saw the carriages and horsemen
and I started to run, that was all."
Zhang Shizhi sent a report to the emperor stating that
the man was guilty of having violated the order to clear the roads
and should be fined.
"But this man actually startled my horses!" the emperor objected in a rage.
"Fortunately my horses are very docile and even-natured,
but if it had been any other horses,
they might very well have upset the carriage and injured me!
And yet you propose to let the fellow off with nothing but a fine?"
"The law must be upheld by the Son of Heaven and by everyone in the empire alike,"
replied Zhang Shizhi.
and that is the penalty the law prescribes.
If I were to impose a heavier penalty in special cases,
then the people would cease to have faith in the laws.
If at the time the incident occured
Your Majesty had ordered the man executed on the spot,
then that would have been the end of the affair.
But now the case has already been referred to me and,
as commandant of justice,
it is my responsibility to see that everybody in the empire is treated with absolute fairness.
Should I once deviate from the standard of fairness,
then the entire legal system of the empire
would loose its impartiality
and the people would be at a loss to know how to conduct themselves.
May I ask Your Majesty to consider the consequences?"
After a long time
the emperor replied,
"The sentence which you propose is quite correct,"
Some time after this a man was arrested for stealing
one of the jade rings from the front of the seat in the mortuary temple of Emperor Gaozu.
Emperor Wen was enraged
and ordered the man hauled before the commandant of justice for trial.
Zhang Shizhi looked up the statutes, charged the man with stealing
the furnishings of a mortuary temple of the dynasty,
and recommended that he be executed and his corpse exposed in the market place.
"In stealing objects from (p.471) the temple of the former emperor,
this man is guilty of the most heinous offence!" said the emperor angrily.
"I send him to you
expecting that you would recommend the death penalty for him and all the members of his family,
but instead you recommend only the sentence prescribed by the statutes.
This is hardly my idea of the
proper respect to show for the ancestral temples of the dynasty!"
Zhang Shizhi removed his hat, bowed his head, and replied,
"The sentence prescribed by the law is sufficient, I believe.
Though actions such as these are all crimes,
there are different degrees in the sacrilege of the offence.
Now if Your Majesty were to execute this man and his family for having stolen objects from a funerary temple,
then supposing by chance some ignorant person were to commit the even greater sacrilege
of removing a handful of earth from the funeral mound of Emperor Gaozu at Changling?341
There would in that case be no harsher penalty left to impose upon such an offender."
Emperor Wen considered the matter for some time and,
after discussing it with his mother, the empress dowager,
decided to let Zhang Shizhi's recommendation stand.
At this time
the marquis of Tiao, Zhou Yafu, and the prime minister of Liang,
the marquis of Shandu, Wang Tiankai,
impressed with the fair way in which Zhang Shizhi administered justice,
became friends with him, and it was not long before
Zhang Shizhi's fame was known throughout the empire.
After Emperor Wen passed away
and Emperor Jing came to the throne
Zhang Shizhi, fearful of the consequences,
pleaded illness,
hoping that he would be relieved of his position.
He was worried that he would be severely punished for the way he had reprimanded Emperor Jing, when the latter was still heir apparent;
he wanted to see the emperor in order to apologize in person,
but did not know how to go about securing an audience.
Eventually, using a plan suggested by Master Wang,
he obtained an interview and made his apologies,
and Emperor Jing took no action against him.
Master Wang
was a devotee of the teaching of the Yellow Emperor and Lao Zi,
who lived in retirement.
He was once summoned to the court and,
because he was a very old man,
was allowed to sit down while the chancellor and the other high officials all stood about him.
"My shoe is untied," he announced and,
turning to Zhang Shizhi, the commdant of justice, said,
"Tie my shoe for me, will you?"
Zhang Shizhi knelt down and tied his shoe.
After court was over
someone asked Master Wang,
"Why in the world did you humilate
the commandant of justice in front of the whole court
by making him kneel down and tie your shoe?"
"I am an old man and in very humble circumstances."
he replied,
"and I doubt that there is anything I can ever do to help Zhang Shizhi.
But Zhang Shizhi is now one of the most renowned officials in the empire,
so I thought that if I deliberately caused him a little humilation
be making him kneel and tie my shoe,
then men would respect him even more."
When they heard about the incident the people of the time
admired Master Wang's wisdom and respected Zhang Shizhi for his humility.
Zhang Shizhi served Emperor Jing as commdant of justice but,
after a year or so,
was transferred to the position of prime minister to the king of Huainan.
The emperor, it seems, was still annoyed with him for his former behaviour.
After some time
Zhang Shizhi died.
His son was named Zhang Zhi
or Zhang Changgong.
He was given a post in the government and advanced as high as counsellor,
but he was dismissed
because he could not accomodate himself to the ways of the time,
and for the rest of his life held no official position.
Feng Tang's
grandfather was a native of the state of Zhao.
His father moved to Dai and later,
after the Han dynasty came to power, moved again to the tomb town of Anling.
Because of his reputation for filial piety Feng Tang
was chosen to serve under Emperor Wen as head of the office of palace attendants.
Emperor Wen was one day passing through the palace grounds in his palanquin
when he stopped Feng Tang and asked,
"How did an old man like you happen to become a palace attendant?
Where is your family from?"
When Feng Tang told him all about his father and grandfather and how they had come form Zhao
the emperor said,
"When I was still living in Dai
my chief waiter Gao Qu often used to tell me about
what a fine man the Zhao general Li Qi was,
and describe to me the battle at Julu.342
Now I never sit down to a meal
without thinking of that battle.
Did Your grandfather know General Li Qi?"
As a general Li Qi cannot be compared
to Lian Po and Li Mu,"343 replied Feng Tang.
"What makes you say that?" asked the emperor.
"When my grandfather lived in Zhao
he was a division general
and was friendly with Li Mu,
and later on when my father served as prime minister of Dai
he was on close terms with Li Qi.
So they had the opportunity to learn what sort of men both of them were."
The emperor had in the past often heard about what men Lian Po
and Li Mu had been and,
slapping his thigh in delight at Feng Tang's words, he cried,
"Ah!
If I only could find men like those two to be my generals now,
I would have nothing more to worry about from the Xiongnu!"
"If I may say so," replied Feng Tang,
"though Your Majesty were to have Lian Po and Li Mu themselves,
you would not know how to use them properly."
The emperor was furious
and hurried off at once to the inner palace.
After some time
he summoned Feng Tang and upraided him.
"Why did you have to shame me in front of my attendants?" he asked.
"Could you not wait until some time when there was no one around?"
replied Feng Tang, apologizing
"I am a worthless man," replied Feng Tang, apologizing, "and I have no knowledge of the proper restraints to be observed."
At this time
the Xiongnu had just made a new assault on the district of Chaona,
invading with great force and killing Sun Ang, the military commander of Beidi Province,
so that Emperor Wen had this problem of the barbarian invaders on his mind.
After a while he began to question Feng Tang again.
"How do you know that I would not be able
to make proper use of men like Lian Po and Li Mu?" he asked.
"I have heard," said Feng Tang,
that when the kings of ancient times sent off their generals to war,
they knelt and, pushing the hub of the war chariots,
said, 'the affairs within the threshold of the palace
I shall direct,
but anything beyond the threshold
I leave to my generals!'
The degree of merit wich the fighters had achieved in battle,
the tiltles and rewards they were to receive,
were all decided by the generals in the field,
and when they returned to court, they simply submitted a memorial to the king to this effect.
And this is no mere empty tale of antiquity.
My grandfather used to tell me that,
when Li Mu was general of Zhao and was camped on the border,
the taxes from the markets set up in the (p.474) army camp
all went to secure provisions for his sodiers.
Rewards were decided by the men in the field
without interference from the court.
The king entrusted full power to his general
and held him responsible for the success of the mission,
so that Li Mu was able to exercise to the full his wisdom and ability.
The court supplied him with a picked force of 1,300 chariots,
13,000 horsemen archers,
and 100,000 of the bravest soldiers.
With this he was able to drive out the Xiongnu ruler in the north,
conquer the Eastern Barbarians,
and destroy the Danlin tribes;
in the west he succeeded in turning back the powerful forces of Qin
and in the south held off the armies of Hann and Wei,
so that in his time
the state of Zhao came near to being one of the greatest powers of China.
but later King Qin,
whose mother was a dancing girl,
came to the throne of Zhao.
Heeding the slanders of his minister Guo Kai,
he finally executed Li Mu
and appointed Yan Ju in his place.
As a result the soldiers on the northern border were defeated
and the state was overrun and destroyed by Qin.
"Now I have happened to hear stories that Wei Shang, the governor of Yunzhong,
uses all the taxes from his camp markets for the support of his men,
and that he even lays out money from his private funds,
slaughtering an ox once every five days
to provide for his officers and men.
This is the reason why the Xiongno stay away from Yunzhong
and do not dare to approach its borders.
If any of them are so foolish as to invade the region,
Wei Shang leads his horsemen in attacking
and killing them in great numbers.
But his men all come from peasant families,
and were recruited into the army directly from the fields,
so of course they know nothing about the proper forms for submitting battle reports.
At the end of a day of hard fighting
they report to headquarters the number of enemy heads cut off and prisoners taken;
but if their is the slightest irregularity in the form of their reports,
then the civil clerks claim that they are not following regulations
and in the end, instead of the soldiers receiving their rewards,
the clerks are upheld in the enforcement of the letter of the law.
It is my humble opinion
that Your Majesty's laws are too detailed,
your rewards too meagre,
and your penalties too heavy.
This same Wei Shang who was governor of Yunzhong has been reprimanded because
of a discrepancy of six persons in his report on the number of enemy dead and prisoners.
Your Majesty has had him tried before the law officials,
and they have not only deprived him of his titles,
but have imposed a penalty on him as well.
That is the reason I say that,
although Your Majesty were to have Lian Po
and Li Mu themselves as generals,
you would not know how to use them.
However, I am a thoroughly ignorant man
and I am undoubtedly deserving of death for speaking out with such impertinence."
Emperor Wen was pleased with Feng Tang哀 words and
on the same day sent him with the imperial credentials
to pardon Wei Shang
and restore him to his post of governor of Yunzhong.
He appointed Feng Tang as a colonel of carriage and cavalry
and put him in charge of the carriage fighters of the military commanders and of provinces and kingdoms.
Seven years later
Emperor Jing came to the throne
and appointed Feng Tang as prime minister of Chu.
He was later relieved of the post.
When Emperor Wu took the throne
he sent out a call for worthy men
and Feng Tang was recommended,
but by this time he was over ninety
and could not again assume the duties of office,
so the emperor instead selected his son Feng Sui to be a palace attendant.
Feng Sui, whose polite name was Feng Wangsun,
was a man of unusual abilty
and a close friend of mine.
The Grand Historian remarks:
Zhang Shizhi knew how to define a worthy man
and to uphold the law without toadying to the will of the emperor,
while Feng Tang's discussions of the way to be a general -
ah! - they too have a flavour about them!
The proverb says,
"If you do not know a man,
look at his friends."
The sayings of these two men are worthy to
be inscribed upon the walls of the court.
In the Book of Documents it says,
"Neither partial nor partisan,
but broad and fair is the way of the king;
neither partisan not partial,
but level and true is his way!"344
Zhang Shizhi and Feng Tang came near to this ideal.
The real name of Wanshi Jun or Lord Thousand Piculs was Shi Fen.
His father was a native of Zhao,
but after the state of Zhao was destroyed by the Qin dynasty,
he moved to Wen.
When Gaozu marched east to attack Xiang Yu
he passed through the region of Henei, where the Shi family was living,
and Shi Fen, then only a lad of fifteen,
became a minor official
in the service of the future emperor.
Gaozu questioned the boy
and was much taken with his respectful manner.
"How many are there in your family?" he asked,
to which Shi Fen replied,
"Of my parents only my mother is living,
and she, alas, is blind.
Our family is very poor,
but I have an older sister
who is good at playing the zither!"
"Do you think you can become one of my followers?"
asked Gaozu.
"If I may have the chance, I will do my best!"
replied the boy.
Gaozu then summoned his sister and made her a lady in waiting,
and appointed Shi Fen as his page
with the task of handling letters and visitor's name cards.
Later the family moved to Chang`an
and lived in the quarters set aside for the families of the palace ladies.
This was because Shi Fen's sister was a lady in waiting to Gaozu.
By the time of Emperor Wen,
Shi Fen had advances the position of palace counsellor
because of his long and worthy service.
He had no knowledge of literature,
but in respectfulness of manner and circumspection he was unmatched by any in the court.
During the reign of Emperor Wen
the marquis of Dongyang, Zhang Xiangru,
who had been acting as grand tutor to the heir apparent,
was relieved of his post,
and the question arose of a suitable replacement.
On the unanimous recommendation of the court,
Shi Fen was appointed as the new tutor of the heir apparent.
When the heir apparent, Emperor Jing, came to the throne,
he advanced Shi Fen to one of the highest ministerial posts,
but he soon found it irksome to have his former tutor so close at hand
and transferred him to the post of prime minister to one of the feudal lords.
Shi Fen's eldest son was named Jian,
his second son jia,
his third son yi,345
and his fourth son Qing.
All were distinguished for their respectful manner and filial behaviour,
and they all advanced to positions in the government
paying salaries of 2,000 piculs of grain.
Commenting on this, Emperor Jing remarked that
"Lord Shi and his four sons all hold positions of the 2,000 picul rank.
The highest honours that a minister can enjoy have flocked to his gate!"
and he gave Shi Fen the nickname of Wanshi Jun or "Lord Ten Thousand Piculs".
During the latter years of Emperor Jing's reign
Shi Fen retired on his salary as a high official
and spent the remainder of his days at home,
only attending court at certain times of the year to pay his respects.
When ever he passed the gate of the palace,
he would always dismount from his carriage and hurry along on foot and,
if he met the imperial equipage in the street, he always bowed from his carriage.
When any of his sons or grandsons who were minor officials
came home from court to pay a visit
he would put on his court robes and receive them
and would never adress them by their family names.
If his sons or grandsons had committed any fault,
he would not scold them;
instead he would retire to his own rooms and, when the meals were served, would sit in front of the table
and refuse to eat
until the other sons had upraided the offenders
and persuaded them to go with the eldest son and,
baring their arms, apologize rspectfully for their faults.
If they corrected their faults,
he always forgave them.
If he was with any of his sons or grandsons who were old enough to wear the cap of manhood,
although it might be an informal occasion, he would always put on his own cap.346
His manner was relaxed,
and with his servants he was pleasant and cheerful,
but at all times circumspect.
Whenever the emperor sent a gift of food to the family
he would always bow his head respectfully before beginning to eat,
as though he were actually in the presence of the emperor.
At funerals
he displayed a (p.479) a profound grief.
His sons and grandsons honoured his teachings
and conducted themselves in the same way,
so that his family was famous as far as the provinces for respectfulness and filial behaviour.
Even the Confucian scholars of Qi and Lu, who prided themselves of their conduct,
all admitted that they were no match for the family of Lord Wanshi.347
In the second year of the era jianyuan (139 BC)
the chief of palace attendants Wangzang
was accused of some faults because of his literay activities.348
Emperor Wu's grandmother, Grand Empress Dowager Dou, was of the opinion
that Confucian scholars like Wang Zang
were strong on words but made a poor showing in actual conduct,
whereas a family like that of Lord Wanshi did little talking
but put their moral principles into actual practice.
On her advice the emperor appointed Lord Wanshi's eldest son Shi Jian
as chief of palace attendants.
Lord Wanshi's youngest son Shi Qing he made prefect of the capital.
Although by this time Shi Jian was old and white-haired,
his father Lord Wanshi was still in good health.
Every five days, when his rest day came around,
Shijian would leave the palace and return home to visit his father.
At this time he always would go to his own rooms and,
summoning one of the servants in private,
would have his father's undergarments brought to him.
These he would wash out in person
and then return them to the servant,
instructing the servant not to inform his father of the matter.
While he was acting as chief of palace attendants,
if he felt that there was some matter which should be brought to the emperor's attention,
he would dismiss the others from the room and speak very openly
and sharply to the emperor,
but when he appeared with the other ministers before the emperor in the court,
he seemed to be unable to say a word.
For this reason the emperor treated him with warmth and respect.
Lord Wanshi moved his residence to another neighbourhood of the capital,
called Lingli.
His youngest son, Shi Qing, who was prefect of the capital, came home drunk one time
and failes to dismount from his carriage at the gate of the neighbourhood.
When Lord Wanshi heard of this
he refused to eat and,
although Shi Qing went to him in great fear and,
baring his arms, begged forgiveness,
his father would not accept his apologies.
Finally all the members of the family, including his oldest son Shi Jian,
went and bared their arms in apology.
"To be prefect of the capital is such an exalted position!"
said their father, upraiding them sarcastically.
"When he comes in the gate, it is quite proper, I suppose,
that the elders of the neighbourhood should scurry out of his way,
while the prefect rides at ease in his carriage!"
After this he accepted their apologies and dismissed Shi Qing.
Form then on, whenever Shi Qing or any of the others of the family
came through the gate of the neighbourhood,
they always dismounted and hurried to the house on foot.
Lord Wanshi died in the fifth year of the era yuanshuo (124 BC).
His eldest son Shi Jian, the chief of palace attendants,
lamented bitterly and was so overcome with grief
that he was barely able to walk with the aid of a staff.
After a year or so
Shi Jian also died.
All the sons and grandsons of Lord Wanshi were noted for their filial conduct,
but among them Shi Jian was the most exemplary,
surpassing even Lord Wanshi himself.
Once when Shi Jian was chief of palace attendents
he had occasion to submit a report to the emperor.
Later, after the report had been returned to him,
he was reading it over,
when he exclaimed in great alarm,
"A mistake in writing!
The character for 凐orse'
should have five lines for the feet and tail,
but this has only four lines.349
One of the feet is missing!
The emperor might have put me to death for such an error!"
[seven lines above]
He was just as cautious and meticulous as this
in whatever he did.
Lord Wanshi's youngest son Shi Qing
served for a while as master of carriage and was coachman
for the emperor when he went out for drives.
Once the emperor, seated in the carriage, asked Shi Qing
how many horses were pulling it.
Shi Qing carefully counted each horse with his whip,
and only then did he hold up his fingers and reply,
"Six horses."
Shi Qing was the most easygoing of all Lord Wanshi's sons,
but even he was as meticulous as this.
Later, when he became prime minister of Qi,
the people of Qi were so impressed by his family's reputation for fine conduct
that he did not have to give any orders (p.4ī) at all
and the whole state was perfectly governed;
the people of Qi even set up in his honour an altar called the Shrine of Prime Minister Shi.
In the first year of the era yuanshou (122 BC)
Emperor Wu designated an heir apparent
and asked his officials who would be suitable to appoint as the boy's tutor.
On their recommendation Shi Qing was summoned from his post as governor of Pei
and made grand tutor to the heir apparent.
Seven years later he was transferred to the post of imperial secretary.
In the fifth year of the era yuanding (112 BC)
the chancellor Zhao Zhou was accused of some fault
and removed from his post.
The emperor sent an order to Shi Qing saying,
"Lord Wanshi enjoyed the esteem of the former emperor,
and his sons and grandsons have distinguished themselves for their filial behaviour.
Therefore let the imperial secretary Shi Qing
be promoted to the position of chancellor
and enfeoffed as marquis of Muqiu."
At this time the Han armies were engaged in an expedition against
the two kingdoms of Yue in the south,
were attacking Korea in the east,
driving back the Xiongnu in the north,
and in the west striking at Dayuan (Ferghana),
so that China was involved in a great number of military undertakings.
The emperor made frequent hunts and progresses about the empire,
re-establishing the shrines of ancient times,
carrying out the Feng and Shan sacrifices,
and working to encourage the revival of rites and music,
so that the public treasuries were depleted.
Men like Sang Hongyang schemed to augment the national wealth by government monopolies,
Wang Wenshu and his group increased the severity of the laws,
Ni Kuan and others were advanced to the highest ministerial posts because of their literary achievements,
and all of them were coming forward with one new proposal after another.
As chancellor, Shi Qing no longer had any say in affairs of government,
but conducted himself with care and circumspection.
Though he occupied the post for nine years,
he was never able to do anything to correct the situation.
At one time he attempted to bring charges against Suo Zhong,
one of the emperor's intimate advisers, and another high minister named Jian Xuan,
but he was not able to carry the case through;
on the contrary, he was accused of misconduct himself
and forced to pay a fine.
During the fourth year of the era yuanfeng (107 BC) it was reported that
there were 2,000,000 people east of the Pass who had wandered from their homes
and another 1,400,000 whose homes were not even registered.350
The high officials discussed what measures should be taken,
and Shi Qing [??] suggested that the vagrants be deported to the border regions
as a punishment for deserting their homes.
The emperor considered that Shi Qing was too old and cautious
to be of any help in the deliberations,
and so he granted him leave to return to his home
and referred the question instead to the imperial secretary and the other junior officials
and interested parties for discussion.
Shi Qing was deeply hurt at the implication that he was not fit for his position,
and sent a letter to the emperor, saying,
"I have graciously been allowed to fill the post of chancellor and,
with my poor abilities, to aid in the government of the empire.
Now the cities are deserted and the granaries empty,
and many of the people are wandering about homeless.
As a responsible official I deserve to die beneath the executioner's axe for such a situation.
If Your Majesty cannot bear to carry out the penalty,
I beg to return the seals which were granted to me as chancellor and marquis
and to be allowed to retire to private life
so that I may make way for more worthy men."
To this the emperor wrote in reply,
"The granaries are already empty
and the people destitute and homeless,
and yet you wish to deport them to the border!
You would stir them to even greater unrest,
increase the gravity of the situation,
and then retire form your post!
And on whom do you propose to shift the blame for what follows?"
Shi Qing was deeply chagrined at the severity of the emperor's reprimand,
and once more resumed his duties as chancellor.
He fulfilled the letter of the law and conducted his affairs with thoughtfulness and care,
but after this he brought forward no more large-scale proposals
for the disposition of the people.
Some three years later,
during the second year of the era taichu (103 BC),
Shi Qing died in office
and was given the posthumous title of Tian, the "Quiet Marquis".
Shi Qing showed particular favour to his second son, Shi De,
and the emperor accordingly recognized Shi De as his heir
and allowed him to succeed to the marquisate.
Shi De later became master of ritual,
but was tried for some offence and sentenced to death.
On payment of a fine he was released form prison and made a commoner.
While Shi Qing held the post of chancellor
a number of his sons and grandsons became officials, and
thirteen of them eventually reached positions paying 2,000 piculs.
After his death, however,
many of them were accused of crimes and removed from their posts,
and the family's reputation for filial conduct and circumspection gradually declined.
The marquis of Jianling, Wei Wan,
was a native of Daling in Dai.
Because of his ability to do stunt riding in a carriage
he was made a palace attendant
and served at the court of emperor Wen.
After discharging his duties satisfactorily for the requisite number of years
he was promoted to the position of general of palace attendants.
He devoted great care and energy to his post and took no thought of anything else.
Once when Emperor Jing was still heir apparent
he summoned some of his father's attendants to join him in drinking,
but Wei Wan pleaded illness and declined the invitation.
When Emperor Wen lay on his deathbed,
he charged his son, saying,
"Wei Wan is a worthy man -
see that you treat him well!"
But after Emperor Wen passed away
and Emperor Jing came to the throne
a year or so went by and the emperor never questioned Wei Wan on any affair.
Wei Wan for his part continued to go about his duties each day with care and diligence.
Once Emperor Jing made a visit to the Shanglin Park,
